Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith voucher No. 266, in favour of J. W. Rutledge, V.S., amounting to $15.00, being fees charged for applying the Tuberculin Test to the cattle in the Kootenay Residential School dairy herd, and making an examination of the barn, etc. I beg to state that this work was done at the request of Dr. E. L. Stone, Director of Medical Services, as reported in my letter No. 1/61, dated October 27th, 1930.

As to the suggestions made by Dr. Rutledge, I beg to report that Mr. Sainsbury, of the firm of Sainsbury & Ryan of Cranbrook, has offered to visit the School with me on the 5th instant and give an estimate of the approximate cost of the necessary alterations. This estimate will be forwarded to the Department without delay.

The above is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

F. S. Ryckman
Constable - Farm Instructor,
In charge Kootenay Indian Agency.

Mr F. Ryckman
Indian Agent
Granbrook B.C.

Dear Sir,

Kootenay Residential School Barn

I the undersigned beg to submit my tender for the alterations & repairs to the Cow Barn as follows:

Replace all broken glass throughout the barn
Remove wood floors in stalls
Repair and replace all concrete after moving wood floors
Build 7 calf pens in north end with gates complete
Remove present Calf pens and replace all necessary concrete
Remove partitions and present water trough then build cow stalls 24 ft on each side with concrete feed trough to match present trough supply and erect 15 cow stanchions also a 6ft water trough
Cut concrete floor 6" deep x 15" wide to form gutter behind cows and cement same with fall to drains
Repair all doors
Remove harness room and then build Bull pen cut a 4ft door through south wall supply door & all necessary hardware
Concrete floor in Bull pen
Build partition to form Harness room and replace door for same
Paint inside of cow barn with two coats of light grey paint
Repair & replace all electrical switches and make good in every respect for the sum of $1250.00

Twelve Hundred & Thirty Dollars

I will give employment to as many Indians as possible

Respectfully submitted

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

We take pleasure in quoting figures for alterations on barn at St. Eugene Mission, Cranbrook, B.C. Said work includes building of cow stanchions, seven stanchions on each side fourteen in all. Removing present calf pens and taking down of partitions, concrete to be cut out, drains to be installed to connect with present drains. Two concrete feeding troughs to be built in to connect with present ones. Moving four iron columns and setting up so they will correspond with new stanchions. Installing one galvanize water trough and connecting same.

Building Bull Pen: Move partition as was shown to centre of double doors leading to harness room. This room to have concrete floor in place of present floor. Work on this pen to be carried out as instructed.

Calf Pens: These pens to be constructed where present horse stalls are, wooden floors to be removed and relaid with concrete. Partitions in stalls to be left as at present but to be extended out about three feet or as far as present ones. Pens to be fitted up with gates and removable partitions across centre of pens.
SAINBSURY & RYAN
BUILDERS AND CONTRACTORS

CRANBROOK, B.C., Nov., 29th, 1930.

New set of doors between cow barn and horse barn. One new door on loft. Present big door at that end of building to be repaired. Twelve electric switches to be installed in present boxes. All broken glass to be repaired also bolts and locks on doors. Interior of barn first floor to have two coats of paint color to be approved by agent.

Our price on the above stated work --------------------- $1273.00

This firm will employ Indian labor on this work as far as possible.

Yours truly,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith estimates received from Messrs Sainsbury & Ryan and Mr. A. E. Jones, contractors and builders of Cranbrook, of the cost of repairs to the cow barn at Kootenay Indian Residential School, this as recommended in the report submitted by Dr. J. W. Rutledge, Veterinary Surgeon, dated November 2nd, 1930.

I beg to state that both the Reverend Principal of the school and myself have gone carefully over the cow barn with the contractors, and we are satisfied that the estimates as submitted will cover all necessary repairs. I also beg to point out that both the contracting firms who have tendered on the work have agreed to use as much Indian labour as possible, this to include the painting of the interior of the barn, and as work is so scarce in the district, this will help the Indians a good deal.

I would respectfully suggest that if the above meet with the approval of the Department that the work be proceeded with at an early date.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

F. S. Ryckman
Constable - Farm Instructor,
In charge Kootenay Indian Agency.

Your obedient servant,

Kamloops, B.C., May 11th, 1931.

Inspection Report, Kootenay Agency No. 6.

St Eugene's Residential School

The farm has been greatly improved. A considerable amount of clearing of bottom lands has been done. This will give good pasture. The irrigation system has been improved and more land brought under cultivation. The new dairy herd was looking fairly well, though not at their best. This was probably due to their just being turned out to fresh green pasture. The useless cows are being gradually killed and eaten. The young departmental bull was in fine shape, and in the end this herd should be one of the best. Mr. George Hay, once of the Agricultural Department, and now in charge of Consolidated Herd (now famous), takes a lot of personal interest in the school herd.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Cranbrook, B.C.,
January 7, 1932.

F. S. Ryckman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Referring to the Ayrshire heifer "Culdares Pansy" purchased from Miss Ogilvy-Wills for the Kootenay Indian Residential School, examined by myself in October last, the Reverend Principal pointed out to me that this heifer had not freshened as was expected and I therefore gave her a thorough examination for that particular defect.

I found on this examination that she was affected with a stenosis of the vagina and that it would be impossible for this heifer to produce a calf. I would like to point out that making a general examination of these animals at the time of purchase Culdares Pansy was supposed to be in calf, therefore it was impossible to detect this malformation without my attention having been drawn to it. I would say that the present value of this heifer is what she would bring as beef.

Trusting this will meet with your approval,

Yours truly,

J. W. Rutledge, V.S.
Granbrook, B.C.,
January 8, 1932.

Sir:

I beg to report that when Dr. J. W. Rutledge examined the dairy herd at Kootenay Indian Residential School on September 15th last he stated that one of the heifers purchased from Miss Jeanette Ogilvy-Wills in October, 1930, and registered as "Culdares Pansy" No. 141025, born April 27, 1928, was a non-breeder and that it would be impossible for the animal ever to freshen. I beg to enclose herewith a letter from Dr. Rutledge in connection with the matter.

Recently the Reverend J. M. Patterson, Principal of Kootenay Residential School, called on Miss Wills to discuss the matter, and although Miss Wills stated that she did not feel that she was obliged to do anything in the matter, she offered to exchange for the heifer a young registered Ayrshire bull of exceptionally good breeding and registered as "Culdares Peter" No. 149711, born March 7th, 1931. The Reverend Principal states that he will be in need of another bull next summer, and as Culdares Peter should then be ready for service, he is of the opinion that the exchange would be of benefit.

Will the Department kindly advise me if such an arrangement meet with approval.

The above is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

F. S. Ryckman,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

In reply I have to say that, in view of the conditions as mentioned by Dr. Rutledge, the Department will approve of the exchange of this heifer for the young registered Ayrshire bull, and the Principal or yourself may arrange to have this exchange made.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith vouchers Nos. 952 and 953, each for $6.00, covering fees of J. W. Rutledge, V.S., for an operation on a cow owned by Indian Baptiste Andrew of St. Mary's Reserve on April 3rd and treatment given the registered Ayrshire bull at Kootenay Residential School on April 30th.

I beg to submit that the cow of Indian Baptiste was in very bad shape, and as she was the only milch cow he owned and the milk was badly needed for his children, I was anxious that the animal be saved if possible. The operation was entirely successful.

The herd bull at Kootenay Residential School was suffering from bowel trouble and I am quite certain would have died without proper treatment. I am pleased to report that the animal has recovered and is now apparently in good condition.

I trust the Department will consider payment of the accounts.

Respectfully submitted,

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

F. S. Ryckman,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am taking the liberty of writing you in reference to a business transaction I have had with the Kootenay Indian Residential School, Cranbrook, B.C., on Jan. 28th this year. I shipped to the above mentioned institution (4) four highly bred Barred Plymouth Rock Cockrels, on the orders from Rev. Father Patterson, but up to the present date I have been unable to get any settlement for same, although I have written several times.

I sent in my account in triplicate as usual in these cases, but cannot get any reply. I would be pleased if you would advise me as to how I can get this matter settled, or if you could get in touch with Rev. Patterson regarding account. Trusting to be favored with an early reply.

Yours very truly,

Mr. Robert Howe,
Acting Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Mr. Howe:

We need badly for next harvest the following:

1. A Binder.
2. A Mower (two horse)
3. A Horse Rake.

A small Threshing Machine would be of great service to us, as we have to engage outsiders at an exorbitant price per bushel.

A small Saw Mill (run by electricity) is a necessity to saw lumber for the School and for our Indians on our Reserves. We are trying to encourage and help our Indians to build homes for each one of their families. We have the loan of a Saw Mill belonging to a Mr. McPhee, a neighbour, but he wants it returned.

Yours truly,

Michael Murphy, P.M.I.
Principal.
Dear Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend Michael Murphy O.M.I., Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, in which he makes application for a Binder, Mowing machine, Hay Rake, Threshing machine and a portable Sawmill.

Ottawa, February 21, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, the Department regrets that, owing to lack of funds, it is impossible at the present time to authorize purchase of the machinery requested by the Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

It is also doubtful just now what amount, if any, will be available in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1936-37. You might, however, write again to the Department about the middle of April in connection with the Principal's request, but it should be distinctly understood that at the present time the Department is not in a position to state whether or not his request can be granted in April.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Robert Howe, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith voucher No. 1504 for $29.52 in favour of Messrs. Little and Atchison of Cranbrook, B.C. submitted by Mr. Indian Agent Irwin for the supply of seeds.

When Mr. Inspector Coleman visited this Agency in February in connection with the status investigation of the St. Mary's Band, he discussed with Mr. Irwin the possibilities of demonstrating to the St. Mary's Indians cultural methods of gardening in view of the wartime necessity for such development and, in this connection, held a conference with the local Provincial Agriculturist, a Mr. Allan, and Mr. Irwin. It was considered that for this year the best method of educating these Indians would be to establish an "Illustration Plot" on the school grounds adjoining the Reserve, having it cared for by the children in order to demonstrate gardening methods to them as well as the adult Indians, and Mr. Allan agreed that he would make a periodical visit to the school and the reserve giving the children and the Indians talks on the plot.

It is noted that Mr. Irwin has marked his voucher as a charge against Vote 79 B.C. Special but if the Department considers that it is equally a school project they may feel justified in charging it to the technical education grant. Actually it serves either purpose.

REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF APRIL, 1944.

School:

The usual activity prevails at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, perhaps a little more so now when seeding operations are in full swing. On the occasion of my last visit, the children under the direction of the Rev. Principal Forbes were busy planting a large number of raspberry and a few currant bushes, about 700 in all. These operations will be followed shortly by the planting of a School garden which will consist of illustration plots of vegetables and grasses. The seeding and developing of this garden is made possible by the action of the Department in supplying the necessary seeds, fertilizers etc. The seeding and developing of the plots will be carried on by the children under the supervision of the Agricultural Representative Mr. James Allan, the Rev. Principal Forbes and the Indian Agent.

The interior of this school is always kept very clean. The meals served are well prepared, composed of wholesome appetizing food. The children too in keeping with the general environment appear to be happily and certainly very clean.

The laundry rooms, never as bright as they ought to have been for lack of proper lighting, have been kalsomined a clean and cheery white which has the effect, despite poor lighting, of making them appear very bright.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1944.

School:

The holiday season has witnessed the return of the pupils of the Kootenay Indian Residential School to the various Reserves in the Agency as well as to the Okanagan from which Agency several were in attendance. In addition to the regular school routine during the last two months, gardening has had a very important place. Seeds supplied by the Department for a school garden were put in by the children. The responsibility of proper cultivation and irrigation was placed on their young shoulders under the immediate direction of Principal Forbes. So far the results are most gratifying. The plot has been carefully weeded by hand, and worked with a single horse cultivator as well as with teams of children using hoes. This fine school's garden if given the same attention by the staff during the holiday season as from the pupils during the last two months. The honours of heavy production may well be shared with the best the Cranbrook District may have to offer. That is how it looks at the end of June.
REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF AUGUST, 1944.

School Garden;

The School Garden has proved to be a project of real importance. Under the direction of Principal Forbes and the muscle and brawn of the pupils, a fine result has obtained, large quantities of vegetables, potatoes etc., are being produced. Sufficient and to spare for the requirements of the School for the remainder of the Fall and Winter months.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Irene Andrew (Bertha Basil), Pupil No. 0251 of the Kootenay Indian Residential School at Cranbrook, who died at Cranbrook, B.C., (place) on September 23rd, 1935.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. Statement of circumstances regarding the death of Mary Antoinette Pascal, aged 8, pupil of the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

At approximately 1:45 P.M. on Saturday, January 21st, 1950, I was called by the Sister in charge of the girls, Sister Mary Joan, to come at once as one of the children had been struck by ice falling from the school roof. I rushed to the girls' yard to find the above-mentioned child lying on the snow near the building with large pieces of ice surrounding her. I picked her up immediately and assisted by the nurse, Sister Paul of the Cross, brought her in the school building and laid her on a bench. A doctor was immediately summoned by telephone. While awaiting his arrival every effort was made to revive her by loosening her clothing and applying wet compresses to her head. The doctor covered the six miles from Cranbrook to the school in record time in spite of the snow and arrived I would say within fifteen minutes after the accident. On his examination he pronounced her dead.

An unusual mild spell following after several heavy snow storms had caused considerable ice to form on the edges of the school roof. The children had been warned of the danger of falling ice and had been told to keep away from the building while playing. This warning had been repeated less than ten minutes before the accident when the junior girls had been sent to the yard to play. The Sister in charge states that she personally directed them to play along the snow banks around the rink where they were making snow-men, which is about a hundred and twenty feet from the side of the school building. During the course of play the victim of the accident forgetting the warning that had been given, began running around the yard and in so doing came close to the school. Her sister and a couple of other girls shouted at her to come away from the building as Sister had said it was dangerous. Their words were hardly spoken when a quantity of ice was dislodged from the roof and fell about thirty feet striking the child and knocking her to the ground. It was in this condition that I found her when summoned.

G.F. Kelly O.M.I., Principal.

COWICHAN INDIAN AGENCY,
QUAMICHEAN, B.C.,
November 19, 1885.

Dear Sir,—It was reported some time ago that the New England Society contemplated, at some future date, establishing an Industrial School for native children on their station at Kuper Island, Chemainus.

As I have held the appointment of Indian Agent for some years, I take the liberty of addressing you on the subject. I do this at the present time that I may urge the great benefit that would be conferred on the Indian children if an orphanage were established at once, if only on a small scale, to be afterwards enlarged and extended into an industrial establishment if thought advisable.

I know of no locality on the coast so well adapted as Kuper Island, where you already have some good buildings.

The expense of establishing an orphanage school there would not be great, while it would have so many advantages. I think that suitable buildings and furniture might be provided for £200, and that a similar yearly outlay would, with the aid of the Dominion grant to Indian schools and subscriptions from Europeans and natives, be sufficient to pay all expenses for a few years to come. I think an orphanage would be the best method starting an industrial school, from the fact that orphan children among these Indians are often neglected, and when at school would not be liable to be taken away, like other children, by the wandering habits of their parents; and, were a good school established, it would naturally draw to it many day scholars, and I fancy also distant Indians would soon be willing to send their children, paying for their board. Of course I mean those Indian who live in isolated positions.

Should your Society be in a position to make any move in the matter, I should be happy to confer with Mr. Roberts.
Dear Sir,—I take the liberty of again urging upon your Society the great benefit they would confer upon the Indians of this coast by opening an Orphanage and School in connection with your Mission on Kuper Island.

I trust the funds of the Company may this year be in a more flourishing condition, and that you may see your way to make a start (even on a small scale) towards the commencement of an institution of this kind.

At the present time there is a strong wish on the part of Indian parents to have their children educated, and there is no place near Chemainus so suitable as yours on Kuper Island; there are so many Indian villages within easy access of it, and no one of them has enough children to ask for a School for themselves; but many of the parents have expressed a wish to send their children as weekly boarders if Mr. Roberts could accommodate them.

Mrs. Roberts is very popular with the Indians and has their confidence, and, I think, would make a successful matron of an establishment of the kind, having under her an assistant and an Indian steward.

I feel sure the Indian Department of the Dominion would be willing to give substantial support to any Society commencing an Orphanage and Industrial School, and none could do so with such a small outlay and with such prospects of success as yours.

The Indians have already requested me to reserve a piece of land adjoining your farm for a School Reserve.

A very great improvement has taken place in the Kuper Island Indians since the residence of Mr. Roberts on the Island; and although the School is small, and Indians often away, the parents are beginning to see the advantage of having their children educated. Last winter, Mrs. Roberts had a night school for young men, and if they were slow in mastering the three "R's" the result has been very beneficial in other respects.

Dear Sir,

I beg respectfully to draw your attention to the "rumor" prevalent in this Province concerning dissatisfaction & indignation among many members of different Native Churches," viz., that the Industrial School for Indian Children, established on this island for the benefit of the tribe along the East Coast of Vancouver Island from Porte & Cowichan is about to be handed over by the Indian Department to the management & the supreme control of the Roman Catholic Church.

I hope the rumor is not true, I hope it is an account of the report I have always had to hear from the Indian Department, & for the Governor who represented British Columbia in the House of Commons.

As I reside on this island, I am here as a missionary of the New England Company, I have been here the last two years. I wish to bring under your notice the following facts:

1. For 17 years I was a missionary of the New England Company at the Big Nation Indian Reserve, County of Bamfield, B.C. My health failing me I came to this province & in the year 1879 Mr. Gilbert & Mr. Powell (both at that time officials of the Indian Department) induced the New England Company to purchase 100 acres of land here, to establish a mission & day school. I paid an official visit to this island in 1879, to see if suitable inquiries as to the land, the desire of the Indians for a school, etc.
I said that bird at the request, given in writing by Mr. Sproul. He recommended this island and the adjacent islands as a most desirable sphere for the operations of the New England Company, the oldest Protestant Missionary Society to Indians existing in England. Neither Mr. Sproul nor Dr. Powell informed me that there was a Roman Catholic Mission on this island, neither did the Indians inform me. And moreover the Indians here assured me that they would be glad to have a missionary sent to them to a day school established among them by the New England Company. In the year 1870 that Company bought the land here, and established a Mission, a day school for the Indians, and ever since that time I have been constantly resident on the island, and the day school & Mission have been in operation. It was some months after I came here that I learned that a Roman Catholic Priest was in the habit of paying a monthly visit of a day or so to the island. He came from Cowichan, some 16 miles distant. He did not reside on Skopey, but I have been constantly residing here. The New England Company expended large sums of money in building a Mission House, a school house, and in carrying on their work for the spiritual & secular improvement of the Indians. Re. the Industrial School at Rupert Island.

I recently visited this school, which is being carried on under the care of Father Donchelé, one of the Missionary Priests of the diocese, and I was surprised and pleased at the manner in which it is conducted. Although having been but six weeks in operation when I visited the school about a month ago, these children show great advancement. There were only 16 children, but scores of others would be willing to come.
When Father Donckle took charge, it was difficult to get any of the boys to remain there at all, but his efforts have made the school an inviting place for the boys, and you could hardly drive away those who are there now.

Improvement to the system, and cheapening to the Dominion Govt might, however, be made, if the priests were given more control. As it is, they find themselves impeded by the regulations, which require them to submit every proposal for expenditure, however small, to the Indian Office; and which require all of the supplies to be ordered by the Indian Agent, and not by the priests. The Indian Agent does not and cannot understand what is required, and the consequence is
is that utterly useless articles are furnished for the use of the school. For instance, instead of small iron bedsteads, which could be procured at slight expense, large three-quarter bedsteads are provided for each boy, one half of the number of which bedsteads only can be put in a room which could accommodate a suitable number of smaller bedsteads. The bedding is necessarily more, and the work considerably in excess of what would ordinarily be required. Clothing is ordered by contract, and is supplied without any regard whatever to the ages of the youths who are to make use of it. The material is of the worst, and it is quite plainly to be seen that some storekeeper has had, and taken advantage of.
of an opportunity for throwing in all the refuse stuff, for the use of the boys, which he could sell to nobody else. The supply of provisions is also upon the same plan. Large quantities of butter and bacon, which the boys could not consume in a year, are supplied, the inevitable result of which is that much of it will go bad—has gone bad in fact already—and be entirely lost; and probably it was not an article fit for food at the time it was purchased.

Being Catholics, of course there is no meat eaten on Fridays; and the regulations require that fish shall be given to the boys at least once a week. It is hardly necessary to remark that there are no fish markets around Rupert Island, and...
and, as you may imagine, the only chance of getting fish is from the Indians, who are there, almost daily, in their canoes, and from whom the article can, at all times, be procured on the spot. But there, again, the regulations step in and prevent the Fathers from getting any fish at all unless they pay for it out of their own pockets, because, before an article — whether it be a pound of fish or a pound of candles — can be purchased, permission has to be obtained from the Indian Agent, who is distant some 25 miles away, and a request and answer could not be made under at least 3 days. The result is that no fish can be procured for these boys, except as
as previously mentioned. I asked Father D'Onckele whether he could not procure the fish, and send in vouchers for his own reimbursement afterwards, but he informed me that the regulations strictly forbade any such proceeding on his part or the purchase of anything, which he had not first of all permission to buy.

The above are only a few instances out of many that might be given of the present state of affairs, small matters in themselves, but at the same time, such as might be remedied, with advantage to the institution, and economy to the Department, for if the priests had the furnishing of all these things they would see that...
that everything purchased was suitable, and bought at the cheapest rate.

It was proposed to the Bishop here, by the Indian Department, that he should accept a lump sum per head, to provide, and carry on the institution. This however, the Bishop could not entertain, as such a proposal might result in a loss and possibly in a profit. The priests, in conducting it, ask no profit, but they certainly cannot submit to the possibility of a loss. The Government can be sure of the institution being run strictly at cost, if given an entire charge of the priests.

I thought that mention of matters pertaining to the school might be of service in discussing the
the subject with your colleagues.

With reference to the letter placed herewith from D.W. Gordon, Esq., dated at Nanaimo on the 2nd inst., addressed to the Hon. the Premier, and in respect to the subject matter of which the Supt. General of Indian Affairs, before leaving for the North West, desired that the undersigned should furnish a report to the First Minister, the undersigned begs to make the following statement:

The rumour mentioned in Mr. Gordon's letter as having recently reached him, that the Principal of the Industrial School at Kuper Island had been notified that after the 1st of January next the Department of Indian Affairs would limit the allowance to be made to that school to a per capita grant of $130.00 per annum for each pupil, the aggregate amount of such allowance to be regulated by the average attendance as shown by the quarterly returns received periodically from the school, is correct. Both the Principal of the Indian Industrial school at Kuper Island and the Principal of a similar

To the Hon. J.J.C. Abbott,

Premier, &c., &c.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6455, file 885-1, part 1)
institution at Kamloops received a notification to the above effect. Since the notice was forwarded, however, to the Principals, protests have been made to the Department by the Roman Catholic Church authorities, under whose auspices the institutions are conducted, against this alteration in the system of payment for the education and support of the pupils, being made; and in a letter received recently from His Lordship Bishop Lemmens, of Vancouver Island, in respect to the proposed change, as regards the Kuper Island institution, His Lordship states that the number of pupils which can be lodged at that institution being at the utmost thirty, the per capita grant of $130.00 per annum would be insufficient to pay the expenses of the institution; that were there, however, lodging capacity for fifty pupils he is of opinion that the Church authorities might undertake to conduct the same on the proposed per capita basis.

The undersigned is of opinion that, while it may not be advisable to at present make the proposed change from the system hitherto followed, namely, the Dept. paying all expenses whatever they may be to the per capita system, it would be advisable to recommend to Parliament that a sufficient amount be voted to admit of such additions being made to the buildings as will increase their lodging capacity to such an extent that accommodation can be afforded to at least fifty pupils at each institution; and the Dept. might then, in the event of this being done, apply the per capita principle of payment for the management thereof to these institutions.
It may, however, be stated that an institution of no greater lodging capacity than either of the above institutions is conducted in the Kootenay country on the per capita principle, namely, $130.00 per annum for each pupil; and the Department has not been advised that any difficulty has been experienced in meeting the expenses thereof.

In regard to the comparison made by Mr. Gordon between the cost during the fiscal year 1890-91 of management of the Industrial Schools in Manitoba and the North West Territories with the cost of conducting similar institutions in British Columbia, the undersigned finds that Mr. Gordon has, no doubt unintentionally, overstated the cost of the institutions in the North West Territories (he gives no figures respecting those in Manitoba).

This doubtless has arisen from Mr. Gordon's taking into account the cost of building and additions made to the institutions, as well as the cost of education and industrial training, clothing and feeding of the pupils. Of course the cost of building should not have been included in an estimate of the per capita annual cost of the pupils. The latter as shewn by the books of the Dept. amounted to for the year 1890-91:

At Battleford $257.56, instead of $404.02 as stated by Mr. Gordon.

At Qu'Appelle $144.31, and not $171.79.

At High River $208.00, instead of $219.41.

And at Metlakahtla (B.C.) $191.81, instead of $217.88.
And as respects the two institutions of a similar type in Manitoba, viz., at St. Paul's, near Winnipeg, and at Elkhorn they are conducted on the per capita principle of payment and receive only $100 for each pupil.

The cost per capita of the Kuper Island, Kamloops and Metlakahtla institutions in British Columbia during the same fiscal year, viz., 1889-90, was:

- Metlakahtla........$191.81
- Kuper Island......157.69
- Kamloops..........153.40.

It may be added that the per capita principle was that upon which it was, in the first instance, proposed that the institutions on Kuper Island and at Kamloops should be conducted; that is to say, that the Roman Catholic Church authorities were to be given the per capita allowance of $130.00 per annum for each pupil and they were therewith to manage the institutions, viz., to feed, clothe, educate and impart industrial training to twenty-five pupils at each institution, or to as many as the buildings would accommodate. Influence was, however, brought to bear by Members of Parliament, and, if the undersigned is not mistaken, Mr. Gordon was one of them, to have additional amounts included in the estimates for those schools, for salaries of employees. Consequently there was a departure from the original intention in the matter of the financial support to be afforded by the Government to the institutions; and now it is found to be most difficult to revert to the more economical scheme.

All of which is most respectfully submitted.

A DAY WITH THE PRIESTS

They Leave Tonight for Their Return in the East.

The Kuper Island School—An Interview with Quebec's Oldest Bishop.

The visiting prelates and priests have been enjoying themselves during their stay here, and all express themselves as highly pleased with the termination of their trip across the continent. Yesterday many of them went up Esquimalt, where they were cordially received on board the warship. The venerable Father La Come, whose history was briefly narrated in Sunday's Columbian, went up to Kuper Island on Sunday afternoon with four other priests. Spoken to by a representative of this paper, he said very pleasantly: "We were all most surprised and pleased at the excellent line of railway that carried us up to Esquimalt. We met there Father Donkels, and we thought he looked very well. He seemed quite refreshed."

Father Lacombe spoke of his visit to Esquimalt, saying: "We were very pleased with the arrangements made, and I was astonished with the great progress that has been made. When we had looked over the place thoroughly, we went to the hospital, visited Indian villages, and the whole population, men, women and children, turned out to welcome us. We found the Indians interested in the two chiefs, being the first Indians to see the whites. They were very friendly, and nothing would satisfy them, after we had been shown around the village, but that we should take them to the church. So we all went to the steps of the church, and I addressed the Indians in my language translated into French to Father Donkles, who in turn translated it to Bishop Demers. I spoke at some length, and told the Indians how much I admired their good behavior. I then asked Father Donkles what pleased his own people would be when he got home to know that their friends on Kuper Island were living such happy, contented lives. He answered me that there were about 6,000 men to live in peace with white men always, and to follow their example in all things. The Indians, who had never seen so many of them well dressed and good.

"I cannot give too much praise, said Father Lacombe, to Governor Royal for their liberality to the Kuper Island settlers or to any of those who have visited among them. For children under his care were the best behaved I have seen for a long time. I saw everything in order, and I am stating that the school is the finest in the Dominion. I have never heard of one at all. It is a magnificent school no doubt. I addressed the Indians myself before we left the mission, and I thought it would encourage them in well-doing. I hope the school will be continued, and that we may make a report to Ottawa about the advisability of doing this soon as I get home."

"Do you consider Canada's Oldest Priest, father, do they not?" asked the reporter?

"Well," said he, "I have done my best for 40 years. I came here to live at first with the whites, and I think that I have succeeded to some extent. I have done my best."

"This afternoon we took the Cree chiefs down to Esquimalt, and on our return to the Warship, we found that they had been ill-fed or constricted by the treatment we received from the whites. We therefore pointed out that the Indians we had with us were big chiefs, did their best to send them back to their homes. After dinner, they took them down among the big guns, worked on deck, and recovered sufficiently from their asthmatism. They were sent back to deck and recovered thereafter. They were not only healthy, but appeared to be able and 'jolly' (grand). I never saw men so nonplussed as when we returned to the city. Our visit must have been the last appearance of any kind of news on board, and it is not to be wondered at."

The reporter, through an interview with Father Lacombe, learned the opinions of the Warships from the Chiefs, but the attempt to make them understand the difference between the Catholic Church and the Protestants had recovered sufficiently from his asthma- tism to eat his dinner, let alone speak of it.

Archbishop Duhamel, of Ottawa, came over from Portland, Oregon, last week, and visited the Bishop Le Pointe, of Three Rivers, visited Bishop Le Flambeau, of Ottawa, just after his second visit to Rome to make arrangements for the Holy Roman Empire, assistant at the Papal Court, and also the Secretary of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre and an Advocate of St. Peter's.

Father La Come is the oldest Roman Catholic bishop in Canada, having been consecrated by his predecessor, the strongest Ultramontane prelate in the Dominion, and is a well-known authority on religious questions and of great research. He was seen, last night, by a very intelligent old man, who speaks English fluently. He has not at all been to speak of his impressions of British Columbia. He declared that he had visited every part of the country, and says that the C.P.R. and the Japan steamers together will succeed in bringing a great number of thousands of people. "I am really astonished," he said, "at the wonderful growth that has been made in this beautiful city. In our church we have always been obliged to turn away a great many poor mission, and when Bishop Demers came to this city he brought officers, but only had one priest with him. Now I see a flourishing place with a large population. Everything is cheaply and plentifully utilized everywhere, and a general air of prosperity and plenty that proclaims progress.

Truly you people are progressing. Why, much of what you have here could three times as old cannot yet be seen.

To-night the sisters at St. Joseph's Convent will give a dancing class, and a supper for which Governor Royal and Judge Routhier accepted invitations. Father Lacombe will go to Vancouver and tomorrow the whole party will take their private yacht and go for a cruise again. Bishop Le Comte will conduct them all safely back. Rev. Father Pay, in Vancouver, will finally before his departure entertain them at a pleasant dinner in his garden.

KUPER ISLAND SCHOOL.

Laosome Tribe Is the Best Industrial School in the Dominion.

The party of Roman Catholic prelates proceeded up to Kuper Island on Saturday to inspect the Industrial School there, returned to the city to-day. The party consisted of Rev. Fathers Lacombe and Bishop Le Comte and Sabine, accompanied by the two chiefs of the Crees and the chief of the Stoisy tribe. Father Lacombe, who has travelled all over Canada, inspected the industrial schools conducted by the Church of Rome, and who is therefore better qualified to speak on the subject than any man in the Dominion, says he is delighted with the Kuper Island institution, and has no hesitation in saying that it is the best in the Dominion. The one fact observable is that it is becoming rather scarce for the Indians to visit it. The building was erected by the Dominion government and is conducted by the Sisters of St. Joseph for the benefit of the Indians. Success has rewarded the efforts put forth by the religious orders of the natives, and the results attained are reason for patronage.

Father Lacombe is enthusiastic over the Kuper Island school, and will probably make another inspection when he returns east.

Bishop Broindel arrived in Victoria today after an absence of nine years. He was astonished and pleased at the change which he perceived everywhere in the appearance of the city. Many parts of the town that he had been changed by the business blocks constructed since he was last here. Bishop Broindel is now ministering in Helena, Montana.

The prelates who attended the Passion Play at Mission last week will arrive in this city this evening. Bishop Duhamel and the prelates accompanied him to Seattle to arrive this afternoon on the Kingston from that city.

MEMORANDUM.

I have read the correspondence herewith relating to the Kuper Island Industrial School. The Principal, the Rev. Mr. Donckele, seems to be labouring under a misconception of the way in which the expenditure for his school is being provided for during the current year. It will be remembered that an attempt was made to enlarge the building at this school, and to provide a per capita grant for 50 pupils. These items went into the Supplementary Estimates for the current year, and were, unfortunately, disallowed, and the Department was thrown back for the maintenance of the school upon the appropriation of $3900 which was provided in the Main Estimates. Of course it would be impossible to carry on the school for one year upon this limited appropriation, and it was never intended to do so. On July 6th I addressed a Memorandum upon the subject to the Acting Deputy Minister, in which I pointed out that the full appropriation for Industrial Schools for the year then commencing was $24,390, and also that, as the expenses for the fiscal year 1891-2 had amounted to $21,300, the Department would not be embarrassed in continuing the schools in the same position as they occupied during the last fiscal year. It was therefore not the intention of the Department to confine the expenditure at the Kuper Island School to $3900; so long
long as the expenditure did not exceed what it was in 1891-2 the Department would be satisfied. The Rev. Mr. Donckele seems aggrieved that the sewing machine and a boat were disallowed by the Department, but he has rather himself to blame for this disallowance than the Department, because when he made a requisition for them he did not give any special reason for requiring them, although at the time he forwarded the requisition he wrote a special letter with it. I think the sewing machine might be allowed, if there is any special necessity for it, and there seems to be such a necessity.

As regards the boat, that I think might also be allowed, if the Principal finds it absolutely necessary. I need hardly say that there is no distinction whatever made by the Department between the Industrial Schools in Canada. It is true that Mr. Scott's salary was increased this year from $800 to $1000, but he had been in the Service for some years, and it was thought that for very many reasons he deserved the increase. I need only cite the fact that Superintendent Vowell was given authority this summer to erect a Laundry and Dry House at the Kuper Island School at a cost of $263 to show that the Department was doing its best to meet the wishes of the Managers of these Institutions. The request for this building was accompanied by a full report showing how desirable it was to erect it, and no similar report was received with the requisition for the sewing machine.

Sir,

I have the honour respectfully to request authority for granting the three weeks' holiday conceded annually by the Department during the month of June in place of July.

As you are aware most of the Indians of this Agency repair to the Fraser River in the month of July in order to find employment in the canneries, and of course their children have to go along and are thus exposed to all kinds of exposure and diseases, evils which they have not to endure so much whilst spending their holidays at home; therefore it is next to impossible to keep any control over the children whilst at the canneries.

By granting this favour to the parents who are desirous of having their children at home for a few weeks in the month of June I think that the pupils would be satisfied with the arrangement, when if no holidays be granted I would apprehend some serious difficulty in keeping some of the pupils at the school during the month of July.

Should you kindly accede to my request I would take it for granted that I may claim the full quarterly grant for those pupils who are absent during the three weeks.

I have the honour to inform you that, owing to increase of work, I have engaged the Rev. J. A. Van Niel as Teacher for the Boys. The Reverend Gentleman is an experienced and capable teacher and will, no doubt, give the greatest satisfaction to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Up to the present time I had done myself all the teaching, besides performing the duties of Principal and supervising the boys at recess, fatigue and farm-work, Mr. D. Gallant attending to the stables and carpenter shop.

I consider that the additional number in the staff will be in the general interest of the school and that the small amount paid out for the teacher's salary will be covered by the increased returns of the farm.

When the school was organized we had no land under cultivation but now we have between thirty and forty acres of arable soil and the work entailed by farming can no longer be attended to by the teacher. OTTAWA, 20th March, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the application from the Principal of Kuper Island Industrial school, received through Mr Ralph Smith, M.P., for an increase in the number of pupils at this institution from 50 to 75, I beg to say that this is one of the oldest of the nine industrial schools in British Columbia and is at present in receipt of a per capita grant of $100.00 for 50 pupils. The same number are provided for at all the other schools, with the exception of Lytton which has provision for 40 pupils, and Coqualeetza, which is paid for 30 children.

Kuper Island school carries on an average about 60 pupils for 10 of whom no grant is paid. They have no difficulty in recruiting and the school is better than the average and has accommodation for the number asked for. Nothing additional is provided in next year's estimates for this school and if it is decided to comply with the Principal's request, provision will have to be made in the Supplementary Estimates.

The Roman Catholics are pretty well supplied with schools in this neighborhood and I think this application might stand for another year.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the application from the Principal of the Kuper Island Industrial School, forwarded through Mr. Ralph Smith, M.P., for an increase in the number of pupils of this institution from 50 to 75, I beg to say that a similar application was made in March, last, through the same source, when Mr. Smith was informed that the Department regretted that it could not entertain the application favourably at that time.

The Kuper Island Industrial School is one of the oldest of the nine institutions of that class in British Columbia, and is at present in receipt of a per capita grant of $130 for 50 pupils, which is the highest number provided for at any of the industrial schools, with the exception of the Methodist school at Coqualeetza, which is paid for 80 children.

The Kuper Island school carries on an average about 60 pupils, being 10 more than the grant provides for; they have no difficulty in recruiting, as the school is popular and well conducted. They are reported to have accommodation for the extra number asked for, but, if the application was complied with, there would be no good reason why the other industrial schools in that Province should not be similarly treated. Further than this, the Roman Catholics have five out of the nine industrial schools under their control, and in the...
same neighborhood they have the Clayoquot Industrial School, the St. Mary's Mission Boarding School, the Squamish Boarding School and the Sechelt Boarding School.

The Deputy Superintendent General,-

Re Kuper Island Industrial School.

The main estimates for next year do not provide for any increased pupilage at this school, but the question of increasing the pupilage will be dealt with when the supplementary estimates are under consideration.

In May, last, Archbishop Orth applied for more pupils, when he was informed that the Department could not then accede to his request. The Kuper Island school carries an average of about 60 pupils, being 10 more than provided for. They have no difficulty in recruiting, as the school is popular. They have accommodation for at least 20 more pupils, but if the application is granted there is no reason why the other industrial schools in the province of British Columbia should not be similarly treated, as they are all, with the exception of Coqualeetza Institute, restricted at present to 50 pupils.

It seems to me that it would be better policy to increase the number of pupils in the schools already in operation than to establish new schools.
Indian Industrial School.

G. DONCKELE, PRINCIPAL

Sir:

Herewith I submit my report of Inspections made during the month of January, 1912:

The Kuper Island Industrial School was visited on Tuesday, the 23rd. The Principal is Rev. D. Claessen. There were 66 pupils on the roll—37 boys and 29 girls. The grant is for 60. Considerable improvement was noted since my visit of last year, principally in the matter of the water closets for the boys. A new water closet building with good sewerage and running water has been installed, and this does away with the objectionable odor noted around the premises on my last visit. The sewer pipe from the girl's water closet is also in a much improved condition from last year, a new tile pipe having been laid, cased partly in cement and now runs out to deep water. The school buildings themselves are very old, and, in places, the foundation posts and sills are rotten. As stated in my report on this institution last year, a new and larger school should be built on the higher ground, as, no matter how much repairs were put into these old buildings, they would still be out of date. There is an excellent farm of forty acres in connection with the school, from which all the vegetables and fruits for the use of the school are procured. The pupils are making good progress with their studies; and the only sickness during the past year were two cases of pneumonia. There have been no deaths. About fourteen pupils have been discharged during the past year, and this has relieved to quite an extent the overcrowded state in the girls' Department.

Sgd. W. E. Ditchburn.
Inspector.

Dealing with the matter of new schools to take the place of old ones, I would say that if there is one school within my inspectorate that requires to be replaced by a new one it is the Kuper Island Industrial School, which is owned by the Government. This school, while not being so old as the St. Mary's Mission Boarding School, is not anything like in as goes a state of repair, and the girls department is entirely too small to accommodate the number of pupils they have there at present. I trust that there will be provision made in the Estimates for the coming session for the erection of a new and larger school at Kuper Island in place of the present one. I have already dealt with the condition of this latter school in my report to the Department for December 1910, in my annual report for 1911, in my report for January 1912 and also in my annual school report for 1912.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
It is my unpleasant duty to report upon a very unsavory occurrence that has taken place at the Kuper Island Indian Industrial School during the present month, in which six boys and five girls—all pupils—obtained egress from their dormitories on various occasions between the 13th and 28th, and, while some of them only participated in innocent amusement, four—two boys and two girls—admitted that they had sexual intercourse on at least two occasions.

I was at Duncan, B.C., on the 23rd inst., about to pay a visit to Kuper Island School, when Rev. A. Urlings, the Principal, telephoned to Indian Agent Robertson, asking him to go to Kuper Island as he was in great trouble; he also asked that Constable O'Connell should go to the school.

Upon arrival at the school on the 24th the Principal explained the reason for his message, and upon our holding a very thorough investigation into this disagreeable state of affairs it transpired that on the night of the 13th the boys got out of their dormitory windows in the second storey and let themselves down to the top of the window casing of the first storey, from which they jumped to the ground. After this first occasion one of the boys obtained a key from the carpenter shop of the school with which he was enabled to unlock the outside door at the foot of a set of stairs leading from their lavatories. The girls got out of a small window 14x17 inches in their lavatory which adjoins

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
adjoins their dormitory and crawled out onto a roof a few feet lower down, and from there got to the ground.

The names of the boys are Lawrence Wilson, Walter Daniel, Willie Joe, Harry Johnny, Baptiste Paul and Michael Underwood, and the girls Elphina August Jack, Cecelia Charles, Alexandria Bazille, Esther Richards and Henrietta Lewis.

As stated above, a searching investigation was held, when all those implicated were brought before us separately, and it was proved beyond a doubt that the two boys, Lawrence Wilson and Walter Daniel were not only the leaders in the movement to break the school regulations by both boys and girls, but were the ones who polluted the two girls, Elphina August Jack and Cecelia Charles. Both these boys and girls admitted their guilt, all the others denying absolutely that they had done any wrong other than getting out of their dormitories, and I have every reason to believe that this is correct, as both the reverend Principal and Sister Superior had the boys and girls before them for private investigation.

Realizing the necessity of stringent measures being taken in this case, in order that it might prove a wholesome lesson for the future, it was decided that the two boys Lawrence Wilson and Walter Daniel should be arrested and brought before a Justice of the Peace on the charge of seduction, the Principal of the school laying the charge, and this was done on Friday, the 25th, at Chemainus before Mr. A. H. Griesbach, N.P., and on Saturday, the 26th he committed them for trial at Nanaimo at the next court of competent jurisdiction.

With respect to the punishment of the two girls, Elphina August Jack and Cecelia Charles, I have advised the Principal of the school that they should be expelled, as their presence in the school might have a bad effect upon the other pupils. As the other four boys and three girls have only been guilty of a breach of the discipline of the school in leaving their dormitories, they were left for the school authorities to deal
deal with, though the Principal is desirous that the Department should state what punishment ought to be meted out to them.

As the mere expulsion of the two boys above-mentioned would not have been considered by them as a punishment for their offence, but more in the nature of a reward, and being something for other pupils desirous of leaving the school before their time, to look forward to, I trust that the Department will approve of the action taken in having Wilson and Daniel arrested, for I believe it will have a very good effect in the future.

At first it might be thought that occurrences of the before-mentioned nature could only result from a lack of watchfulness on the part of those in charge of the school, but in this instance no blame can be attached to them. The fact that some of the children often get out of their beds at night and go to the lavatories is such a natural proceeding that no particular attention is paid to them when they do so. One of the teachers sleep in a little room off the dormitories, and, so long as no noise is created the pupils are not remonstrated with.

In order that the case of these boys may have the least possible publicity, I have instructed Constable O'Connell to endeavor to have them come up for Speedy Trial at a private hearing. Of course all the pupils at the school have a full knowledge of this matter already, and it will eventually find its way to some of the parents, but otherwise it has been kept from the public, and I trust, in the interest of the Department's educational system, that it will remain so.

Indian Industrial School Opening

The opening of the new Kuper Island Indian Industrial school was off without a single hitch on Tuesday last. Hundreds of Indians, men, women and children came from near and far for the occasion and, with about a hundred of their white brethren, gathered in the school yard to enjoy the hospitality of the Rev. Father Lemmens and his courteous staff.

In the morning Rear Admiral W. O. Story and Miss Story arrived on the Maida, Capt. H. H. Shepherd, M.P., and the Rt. Rev. Bishop MacDonald and a guest came on board. They passed along the wharf, decorated with flags and bunting, to the imposing three-story brick edifice which replaces the old wooden school built in 1890.

After an excellent lunch in the girls' work room, the ceremony referred to above took place. It was the 26th anniversary of the foundation. Since then 342 pupils had passed through the school. It was the request of the late Bishop Lemmens that the government erected the first school, aid being given by Mr. Gordon, then M.P. for Nanaimo, who said he should be honoured. He paid a glowing tribute to Mr. Gordon, which has been continued in the present building; to the Indian department; to the firm of Gordon Co., Canadian contractors; and to Mr. Myles Morley, inspector of schools.

Mr. Gordon most neatly described the credit for the new school to Father Lemmens' persistence and devotion.

After the service was held in the beautiful chapel in the building the ceremony of raising the flag was performed by the bishop. Its sprinkling with holy water was prefixed by a prayer. His Excellency said that this was a red letter day in the annals of those noble tribes whose ancestors had dwelt in this land from immemorial times. The building itself was a mark of the provident care which the government had for its Indian wards. They owed it to the government which had always extended its protection to the Indians.

The bishop had worked first in the field and had proved to be a most helpful friend to the Indians, of which the government had so generously seconded. That work was the upliftment of the aborigines, the normal inhabitants.

In the past days missionaries went down into the Indian camps and shared their lives; now the government had brought them together, the children of those tribes to share the life that civilization, the arts and sciences enabled.

This great building was worthy of the government and of the Blessing of God, be the means of doing great good. They had come to help the Indians, dedicated to the service of God and humanity.

Following the blessing the Union Jack was raised by the building by Mrs. F. H. Shepherd, Admiral Story's leading lady. The band played while the children sang "Three Cheers for the Red, White and Blue." It also played "O Canada."

Memorable Scene

The bishop in his robes, with attendant priests and acolytes, stood on the high entrance porch. They looked down on a great gathering. The girl pupils, attired in neat grey and blue and marshalled by kindly sisters, stood in rows. The old Indians of all ages gathered near, while, farther on, the eye travelled down to the wharf where the launch slowly entered, over to the grim grey bulk of the steamer. A picture of the scene had been taken one of the finest views in the province, across the grey, smooth expanse of the Salish Sea, by Mount Brenton.

Speeches from the porch followed. The first was introduced by Father Lemmens, Mr. F. H. Shepherd, who said he was very pleased by the visit. It was his pleasure as a representative of the Dominion government to congratulate the bishop, fathers and sisters, on the efforts which had resulted in an edifice which would stand for centuries. It perpetuated a tribute to the people whose ancestors had dwelt in this land and an evidence of the recognition of the debt owed to the Indians. We had been working hard at getting to assimilate them.

He wished to pay the highest tribute to each of those clergy present. He was not a member of it, but he knew the work in the Cariboo and Alaska, its evidence of Christianity in alleviating sickness and distress.

To Mr. Gordon, Mr. Shepherd said that the building was dedicated for them. Their gratitude, if they responded similarly, would some day bless the fathers and sisters who had done so much.

To Mr. Duncan Campbell Scott, deputy superintendent of the Indian department, Mr. Shepherd paid a glowing tribute for his help in aiding his representations. The building would stand as a monument to the skill and integrity of the Island builders and craftsmen. He thanked Mr. Shepherd for raising the "first flag on earth, the flag that never comes down."

Lesson of Freedom

Rear Admiral Story took the flag as his own. It was a symbol which meant that everyone should be free to work out his own salvation. For that was the object of the new school would teach the boys and girls how to earn their living and give them worldly, combined with spiritual wisdom. It was the happiest thing possible to have such a school to do. Here they would learn that what was best for them was best for the world. They would be taught to be good Catholics of whom there were 500,000 in the world, speaking the same head, His Holiness the Pope. If they carried their teaching with them throughout life, they could become citizens of the greatest empire on earth.

Mr. W. E. Ditchburn, superintendent of Indian agencies, B. C., recounted his experiences with getting this building project started. Some people were sufficiently ungenerous and unwilling to see that the government did not do enough for the Indians; some were generous.

The government desired to bring the aborigine up to the standard of the white man and this could be begun only education. He quoted figures showing that in the past ten years $138,697 had been expended on education among the 25,000 Indians in the province, an expenditure of 5.5 cents per head. In the past year $33,279 had been spent in medical and hospital services. If the good work would go on and, if the Indian did not take advantage of the facilities offered, it was not the fault of the department.

Speeches in Chinook

Mr. W. R. Robertson, Cowichan Indian agency, spoke to the Indians in Chinook. His remarks were frequently punctuated with applause.

Chief Edward Halibutson, Penelakut, addressed the gathering of men, and presented an address to Mr. Shepherd asking for still more accommodation for educated children. The member promised to do all he could.

Bill Quinamuck, of Quinamuck and a picturesque figure and Indian lawyer, completed the speeches.

Canoe racing followed. Cowichan Indians won the big race, seven in a canoe, from Valdes and Indians, by three quarters of a length after a race ranging from Duncan to Cowichan by road. The football game was excellently and beautifully decorated, and at which the girls and boys sang and recited songs and poems.

There is much to see in the building, of which Mr. R. W. O. O. O. was the architect. A description of it will be given later. The choice of materials employed today were a tribute to the excellence of the culinary department and its staff.
Old School for Education of Indians at Kuper Island

NEW INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL OPENED

Dedication of Kuper Island Institution Takes Place — Bishop MacDonald and Mr. F. H. Shepherd Present.

Tuesday, June 6, 1916, will be a memorable date in the annals of the work of the Government of Canada for the Indians of Vancouver Island. It will mark the successful culmination of a series of efforts extending over many years to secure to the native children the fullest opportunity to enter into the enjoyment of the same benefits of civilization which are possessed by white people and to take their place among the educated citizens of the country. The new building for the Indian Industrial School at Kuper Island is designed to provide the best possible education of Indians shall be equipped with modern educational apparatus and modern comfort should go a long way towards facilitating the task of bringing the ways of civilization and moving them to elevate their standards of living.

The Indian Industrial School at Kuper Island was built in 1899 by the Dominion Government for the Indians of the Cowichan Agency. Its first principal was the Rev. Father Donceel who, for twenty-three years, worked with untiring zeal amid apparently insuperable difficulties to place the work on a solid foundation. Father Donceel died in 1907, worn out with his labors. The Fathers of the Congregation then took charge of the work. The Rev. Fathers Urschitz, Schuster, and Rev. Father W. Lemmens, who was appointed in 1913, have successively held the office. The services of the Fathers have been loyally seconded by the Sisters of St. Ann, who have had charge of the school since 1907.

Father Lemmens saw at once, on his assumption of charge, that he had reached a stage where the old buildings were neither large nor modern enough to accommodate the increasing number of pupils. He therefore implored Mr. Frank Shepherd, the energetic member for Nanaimo in the present Parliament, to lay the claims of the institution before that body. The Rev. Shepherd did, with such success that it was possible to dedicate on Tuesday last the magnificent new building which was the admiration of all who saw it.

Imposing Structure

The new building is an imposing structure, finished in red brick, and provides accommodation for 160 pupils. Its equipment is of the most up-to-date character. There are classrooms, large airy dormitories, well-stocked workshops for the boys and fully-appointed practice kitchens and laundry for the girls, providing the principal teachers with all possible means of attaining their great object.

A goodly number of visitors journeyed to the beautiful island on Tuesday to take part in the festivities. The Indians began to arrive at an early hour from all parts of the agency, and fully 100 were gathered on the beach by the time the dedication ceremony commenced. Among these were many former pupils of the school.

The White visitors included Right Rev. Alexander MacDonald, D.D., Bishop of Victoria; Rev. Father Horne, of Nanaimo; Mr. and Mrs. Sheppard, proprietors of the Island; Rev. Fathers Silver, and others, of Victoria; Mr. McLean, of Ladysmith; Scheele, of Port McNeill; of the staff of the school; the Mother Provincial of the Sisters of St. Ann, and Mrs. Horne, wife of the Mayor of the Esquimalt naval station, and Miss Murray; Mr. Frank Shepherd, M.P. for Nanaimo; Mr. Sheppard; Mr. W. Ditchburn, Inspector of Indian Affairs; Mr. C. Carter, Inspector of Indian Schools; Mr. W. R. Robertson, Indian Agent for the Cowichan District; Mr. W. G. Oliver, Post Office Officer; Mr. R. H. Fletcher, Post Office Inspector; with Mr. Fletcher; Mr. Smith, of the Naval Building Committee; with Mrs. Smith; Mr. Miles Morley, superintendent of the school; Mr. and Mrs. Robinson, of the school; Mr. and Mrs. O'Connell, of Victoria, and many others.

The proceedings began with luncheon, served in the "catering" department of the new building. Over 100 guests sat down at table. After Mr. Frank Shepherd had delivered his address, he claimed the whole credit for the completion of the work to the late Father Lemmens, who had left him no peace until he had persuaded the authorities in Ottawa of the necessity of the building. He appreciated the presence of so many visitors testifying to the interest shown in the work and the importance of the cause of uplifting of the Indians.

Blessed Buildings

After luncheon the Bishop of Victoria proceeded to the blessing of the building, which was carried out according to custom.
he taught the truths of the Catholic Church, and if they lived up to them they would be more likely to attend usual offices of the Mass. The Fathers and Sisters would teach them this, but they might not have the opportunity or the business to do this. Well, he said it too, and he was an old man of the sea who had seen the best and worst of scenes of life. He trusted that the new school would be a great source of material and spiritual benefit to all of them.

Higher Civilization

Mr. W. E. Ditchburn, Inspector of Indian Affairs, was the next speaker, and said it afforded him much pleasure at being present for the formal opening of the school. He spoke in view of the fact that he felt that he was to some extent, responsible for its construction, as he had recently visited the Government officers at Ottawa the desirability of replacing the old building by the present substantial structure which had been suited to the Government's policy of educating the Indians, in order that they might reach a higher stage of civilization than that on which their forefathers had been left behind.

As a representative of the Department of Indian Affairs, Mr. Ditchburn thought it his duty to make a few remarks to those who sometimes say that the Government is doing too much for the Indians, and that the Indians themselves, as well as others who maintain such unsparingly, are far from the Government doing enough for the Indians. To the former Mr. Ditchburn said that the Government of Canada realized its duty to its wards, the Indians, and proposed, if possible, to do so much for them as in the future take his place in the commercial and industrial world along with his white brothers. Mr. Ditchburn said, could only be realized by the Indians rising to the level of the white race. They had been given an education and for this purpose the Government of Canada was spending $1,186,367.16 during the past ten years, which aggregated $11,865,616.24. The amounts are as follows:

Mr. Ditchburn explained that during the past ten years five residential schools had been built at Alert Bay, St. Eugene Mission, Carcross and the present one at Kuper Island, which had been dedicated that day. A large number of day schools had also been built. He also went on to show that the Indian population of British Columbia had been steadily increasing, the increase close to the 25,000 mark, which would show a per capita cost for the ten years of approximately $45.00 or a total per capita cost of 47 cents. Mr. Ditchburn also said that another item of expenditure in connection with the charge of the Indians was that for their medical care, which included medical attendance, medicines and hospital work in the fiscal year alone reached the sum of $44,370.00.

Good Work to Go On

Mr. Ditchburn said that after reading about the school he trusted that the Indians would appreciate the good work the Government was doing in their behalf, but whether or not the fruits of the Government's work were the amount of appreciation they were entitled to, the good work would still go on until each time as such educational facilities were provided for the Indian children of should be loyal to the Government and loyal to the church.

Chief's Address

After the address Bishop MacDonald, chief of the Kuper Island Indians, read an address to Mr. Shepherd on behalf of the Indians of the Island, thanking him for the efforts he had made to bring about the building of the new school. He thanked Mr. Shepherd for the assistance and the interest shown in the Indians. He took advantage of the occasion to make a point not noticed by Mr. Sheppard that the school was still too small and that not all the children who would like to go there could be accommodated. He asked Mr. Shepherd to use his influence to procure a larger grant permitted by the natives. Later that evening on land, and the whole was concluded by a further address by Mr. Sheppard, Mr. Cowichan and the team of the school, which ended in a draw.

In the evening a supper and entertainment was provided, chiefly by the girls, although the brass band of the school, under the direction of Father DeWaeer, had already taken a prominent part in the day's proceedings, and further added to the programme. The programme of the entertainments was as follows:

Greensleeves; "Silver Jubilee"; jubilee song; physical culture, dumb bell; rope swinging; action song, "Busy Little Workers"; "The Indian Hunters"; salute to our flag; concert piece, "Our Beautiful Land"; song "O Canada."

These items were interspersed with selections by the band. Those present were struck with the earnestness of the children's enthusiasm, their grateful expression of the kindness of their friends and the general evidence their performance gave of painstaking training. At the close of the celebration, the Kuper Island Schools, gave expression to the deep satisfaction they felt in witnessing the performances and said that they greatly respects the Indian Industrial schools over the province, the paternal schools of the Province. As examples, he mentioned the division of the day into half a day's instruction and half a day's manual training. He said that a scheme was being tried under which still more attention would be paid to the question of manual training, so that it should be more effective. He was very pleased with all he had seen and hoped he would see the new school every success and blessing.

The singing of the National Anthem brought to a close all the festivities, which will remain long in the hearts of those who had the happiness of experiencing it. The new school promises to be a line to play an important part in the history of the Indians of the Island.

INDIAN EDUCATION

To provide a further amount for Educational purposes.................. $1,400.00

The Department has a new industrial school building at Kuper Island, which was opened in June 1916, with accommodation for one hundred pupils. It has an enrolment of 82, with an average attendance of 78, with a per capita grant of $140.00 for 75 pupils.

The proposed increase of ten pupils in the number provided for is required to meet the educational wants of the Roman Catholic children on the Quamichan Reserve in the Cowichan Agency.

The Day school formerly carried on there was closed last July for want of attendance and for the reason that the building in which the school was conducted was condemned and was totally unfit for occupation. The Indians of this reserve are of nomadic habits and leave the reserve at least six months in the year in order to make a livelihood at the fisheries and as they take their children with them, they receive little or no benefit from the day school and it is thought that by transferring them to the Kuper Island Industrial School, where there are already a number of children from this reserve, they would be in a position to receive a good education.
Ottawa, July 30, 1918.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that the Supplementary Estimates for Indian Education for the fiscal year 1918-19 provide for an increase of ten pupils in the number already provided for the Kuper Island Industrial School. It is not the intention to re-open the day school on the Quamichan Reserve, as there is ample accommodation in the Kuper Island Industrial School for the children from that reserve.
