At the time of my visit to this school this summer, the following matters were brought to my attention: Land is badly needed - there are 75 acres at present. Mr. Agent Lomas would like something done in an effort to quiet the older Indians of the band who insist that they were to have been paid for this property. Fifty acres to the east of the school site is reserve land, not settled and might be acquired.

Grapes, walnuts, fruits of all kinds, all vegetables and some of the potatoes are raised. They have 7 milch cows and 3 horses, but not enough land to raise beef. Water supply and acetylene lighting systems - in good condition. They have enough water to irrigate all of the 50 acres that are cultivated, from the reservoir.

I found here the best gymnasium at any Indian school in Canada. There is a spectators' balcony, dressing rooms, lavatories and playrooms - all in the gymnasium building. There is a splendid Band here: they need a few more instruments at this time. They have splendid manual training equipment, but no instructor. Mr. Cairns suggests a Government manual training instructor to travel among the 5 or 6 residential schools on the mainland.

The barn is fairly adequate - the hennery and piggery are good - excellent laundry equipment - good bakery and dairy - heating O.K. The bake oven needs repairs and they will write about this. I noticed in the pig pen a splendid swing swivel wall over the trough.

R.F.F.
I do not think these pupils are well fed. I have gone into this matter with the Principal very thoroughly. All the milk is separated. That means that all the butter fat is taken out of the milk and the pupils receive skim milk. I went into the boys' dining room at supper time. Here is what each boy had: soup, bread and apple sauce, and tea with milk. If I had my way I would banish every separator from these Industrial and Boarding Schools. The pupils need the butter fat so much.

x x x x x x x

Eva Hall died May the 5th after an operation for the removal of the appendix. Mary Siah, aged 15 years, died of peritonitis September 3rd, 1922. Joseph Jacob died in July some ten or twelve days after being discharged. I could not find out the cause of death. I presume that he was about 18 years of age.

Then you will see by this report that 11 are now out on sick leave. The Indians are inclined to boycott this school on account of so many deaths.

May I be permitted to suggest that the Doctor who visits this school monthly be requested to send into the Department a report on the health of the pupils of this school. I would also ask that a copy of his report be sent to me.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report dated November 9th, last, on his inspection of the Kuper Island Industrial School, has drawn attention to the food supplied the pupils. He states that he considers they are not well fed; that the children are given milk which has been separated and all the butter fat removed; and that the other articles of diet are meager and not of a nourishing quality.

As milk is one of the chief articles of diet for children, the Principal should see that an ample supply of pure milk, containing all the butter fat, is furnished for their use. Butter should be made only from any surplus milk after the pupils have obtained a reasonable quantity. You will be good enough to draw this matter to the attention of the Principal and see that the Department's requirements are carried out.

You should instruct the Doctor who visits this school monthly to examine the children and furnish a report on their health. There have been a number of deaths during the past year and, as a result, the Indian parents are inclined to boycott the school. The Doctor should examine into the food furnished and ascertain whether it is ample and contains sufficient nourishment for the needs of the children. It might be well if he would give the Principal his advice regarding the quantities and kinds of food that should be supplied. We will be pleased to receive a report made by the Doctor regarding the diet supplied at this school, and any recommendations which he desires to make. You will please give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Our role of pupils, according to present grant, is full; and under present conditions we cannot accommodate more pupils. Yet just now I have already 6 new applications on hand and with a small effort more could be had. I think it is a pity that we cannot give all these children an opportunity of learning something. By doing this we easily find accommodation for 100 pupils in the present building. The class-rooms and dining-rooms are big enough. Presently the only difficulty is for the dormitories; but this would be overcome by replacing 24 big size beds (6ft.long for children of 7,8,9 years old) by 32 smaller size beds (5 ft Long). In this way there would be 24 bigger boys and 24 bigger girls in their respective dormitories; and 26 smaller boys and 26 smaller girls in their respective dormitories. Dear Sir:-

Having just completed a comprehensive survey of all the Indian Missions of this diocese I feel I should write you at this juncture to stress a few of the major considerations.

(I) In regard to certain accusations made against Kuper Island School details of which I have no doubt certain elements would be sure to provide you with "in extenso" I can now declare my candid opinion that the school as such is not involved at all though there was one priest, a convert to the church from protestantism, and not a member of the Kuper Staff whose conduct to me at any rate does look quite blameworthy. What view, however, a sane jury would take knowing to what lengths of mendacity Indians can go when pushed on by subversive elements, is an entirely different matter. I am glad you realize I have done all in my power to facilitate the necessary inquiries into the situation and that I will as in the past cooperate with the department to the maximum in achieving any ameliorations suggested. Though quite cognizant of certain lamentable breaches of morality in connection with individual members of certain public institutions in this province, I have always taken the quiet way in quest of amendment because I fail to see any advantage in ruining an institution because of some individual's supposed or even real misdeeds. If in such cases Royal Commissions are going to be accorded generously, then assuredly no one in the Dominion would be out of work!
(2) In regard to the East Coast Agency I wish to press very strongly for the appointment of Mr Bernard Francis Neary, a talented young man, fond of the Indians and provided with the very best of references. He happens to be a Catholic but I feel under the circumstances this should only add to the opportuneness of his appointment because the majority of the Indians being Catholics, the bishops are growing more and more nettled to find a Catholic nominee never seems to be contemplated. One of their number said "What we require is an Indian Catholic Emancipation Act". Moreover with all due respect to Mr Graham, his inefficiency on the East Coast has caused us plenty of inconvenience not to use a harsher word and Mr Chambers the local liberal representative though not a Catholic on his own initiative called on me to state his conviction that Mr Neary would be the logical nominee. To give you some notion of his qualifications I am taking the liberty of enclosing a memorandum in case you may not be personally familiar with the man's standing.

(3) On the West Coast I believe Mr Ashbridge has striven conscientiously to fulfil his duties and though I do not always see eye to eye with him I certainly feel he is a worth while agent in every regard. To my mind the most disturbing factor on the West Coast is the Ahousat School where sickness and trouble seems to be perpetually rife. I am not blaming the present staff but I do feel the Indian Act was strangely contravened when a second residential school was put so close to Christie School and the net result was that the white men's sad religious wrangles were also and quite unnecessarily visited upon the Indians. However things being as they are probably a day school would be the best solution - if any school there at all.

With personal regards and the earnest hope that Mr Neary's application will be accepted I remain

Yours sincerely,

A further complication is found in this that the school owns no standing timber; if it did the wood could be cut in times of emergency such as these by the school staff. I have tried to make some agreement with the Indians in that sense, but there is so much wrangling between them to ascertain to whom property or limits belong that if we ventured to do our own cutting, there would be no end to trouble. Even in normal times, with the usual fishing, hop-picking and work in canneries, there is no certainty as to the possibility of one hundred and fifty cords of wood being cut and hauled in due time. As appears the alternative would be for the school to own some woodland where the staff or any other hired help could carry on operations in times of urgent need.

All this makes it difficult to meet financial obligations with an irregular attendance such as prevails yearly at the beginning of the school year, and proves to militate in favor of some betterment in that regard.

I must admit that the "bonus" received in the two past years has helped considerably to tide over these conditions, but I must also say that previous to receiving that help, much of our personal salaries were used to make purchases and that to date some three hundred dollars of back salaries are still to be paid. Dear Sir:

I take the opportunity to inform the Department about conditions prevailing here, mostly all anent the financial status of the school.

Yearly there is approximately a decrease of five hundred dollars in the grant for September quarter, due to the fact that the children never return to the school on opening date. A good number are enlisted to work in the hop fields, early in August, and these are the ones who return to school very late; there are some who work in the Canneries, and some who just "idle" around.

This year I had the holiday period begin on June 15th, to end on August 15th, with the hope of having the hop-pickers return to school in due time, but to no avail. Those who were still in the Country filled in one after another by force of the warning they got from the Police or the Indian Agent.

The hop-pickers are really the ones that create a problem, for the one reason that they are beyond reach of Police action, and for the other reason that they offer those who remain in the Country the pretext that without the full roll of pupils in school, their are no regular class periods and therefore no reason for merely being present.

Every year, it would be possible of course to fill in vacancies with new-comers, seven and eight years old, but as a consequence the roll would be made up of fifty per cent of these "tots", and they are not capable of doing the work required by these Industrial schools.

It might be desired that I should go and round up the former pupils myself or through one of the staff, but I must say that the location of the school being on an Island as it is, this procedure would prove to be very costly as I would have to hire a car or a truck to cover places all over the Island and nearby Vancouver. To reach these points by boat, would be mere loss of time. However in this regard I may say that this year,
there has been some organization on the part of the Indian Agent and
the Provincial Police to better this condition, and I am particularly
grateful to Mr. Moore for his readiness to cooperate to the best of his
ability, but I beg to state that more should be done, and would suggest
that all school children be rounded up previous to their departure for
the hop-fields.

I was stating that all these remarks bear a relation to
the financial condition of the school and this appears when considering
that due to the absence of a good number of pupils at a time when there
is great need of help on the farm to gather in the crops, the per capita
grant being less, I am not in a position to hire much needed help, also
that I cannot afford paying for transportation if it be a question of
gathering the children myself.

As regards means of transportation for the usual convenience
of the school, there is this also that we are now using a mission boat
owned by the clergy of the Diocese, the engine in the school boat being
unserviceable. I have made a request to obtain another, but was told
the school would have to defray the expense. As further consideration on
this matter, I beg to state that the present school boat, though in good
condition, the engine being left out, is not in keeping with the require-
ments of transportation for an Institution such as this, things being
such nowadays, that trips some five miles across to Chemainus Hospital
for various clinics, have to be made with good number of children aboard
and in any weather. The reason for this organization is that our D.C.
Electrical plant is not serviceable for X Rays and other equipment.
A bigger, faster and more comfortable boat would be needed; this the school
cannot afford to pay for.

Also that presently we have to buy bread at twice the price
it takes to make it, due to the fact that our present oven is useless,
and that the delay occasioned by the purchase of a new one may still be
extended.

Lastly, to be considered also, that fuel wood, a country-
wide problem, no doubt, offers complications here also, even though there
is plenty of standing timber all around us. The difficulty lies in the
fact that even with a raise of one dollar and one half in cost per cord,
to encourage Indian labor and assure our quota for the year, there is no
prospect of satisfaction, because the Indians are making big money every-
where else and find good opportunity all year round.
Ottawa,
October 28, 1943.

Dear Father Camirand:

I have your very interesting letter of the 21st instant and appreciate the many difficulties under which you are labouring at the present time. Part of them, no doubt, are due to present conditions which other residential schools throughout Canada are also experiencing. I presume that the Indian Agents concerned will give you every possible assistance in returning to the school pupils whose leave has expired. Of course, there is such a demand for labour at the present time that the older boys can easily obtain work and consequently I can understand that it may be very difficult to have them returned to the school.

As you realize, manufacturing conditions today are very difficult and, as a consequence, there is a great deal of delay in securing any new equipment that is required. The order was placed for the bake oven on the 29th of September and the firm was requested to rush delivery. Immediately on receipt of your letter I got in touch with the Purchasing Branch and they are writing a letter to the firm giving them a special priority and urging them to have the oven shipped at the earliest possible date. In spite of all we can do there will still be some delay, as transportation is rather slow.

I still retain many kind recollections of my last visit to Kuper Island some three or four years ago.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. J. Camirand,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kuper Island, B.C.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indians Graduated

Graduation ceremonies were recently held at the Indian Residential School on Kuper Island. School colors, class pins and framed diplomas were presented to Clifford P. Thompson, Williams; James Francis Cooper, Craigflower; Benjamin Paul, Saanich; Levi J. Goldsmith, Saanich, and Denis B. Charlie, Duncan.

Entertainment included a play, choral numbers, recitations and personal addresses. Examples of Indian arts and crafts were displayed in the home economics room. Honor rolls were presented to 83 students who received promotions in the various grades.

Visiting clergy included Revs. G. Penfold, J. J. Cyr, X. Lauson, H. Bequin, M. Lariviers and C. Stone. Representatives of the Catholic Women's League were also present.
Sister Theodore
70 Years a Nun

VICTORIA, July 21. — Seventy years in the black habit of a nun is the remarkable record set up by Sister Mary Theodore, SS. Sister of St. Ann, who next week will be honored and feted by her many friends and former pupils at St. Ann's Academy here.

It was in 1878, a few years after joining the order in Montreal that Sister Mary Theodore came to Vancouver Island, serving for a time in the Indian School at Duncan.

Bright and active, despite her years, Sister Theodore goes about her daily duties in the academy here, being in charge of the museum which she largely built up herself.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Payments of Grants
Sir:-

I have the honor to ask again the Department to allow us the full quarterly grant, i.e. $1950.00, although we have not the required number of children. It is impossible for me to meet ordinary expenses. As you can see by the financial statement I incurred a heavy deficit last year, owing to the high cost of living, and many improvements we made. We cleared and fenced with wire fence 8 acres of land, and planted 2 acres with apple and pear trees. New farm implements being much needed, I bought a wagon and harness. Besides that we lost our best milk cow.

I hope the Department will consider this and grant the request.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the September quarter return of the Kuper Island Industrial School, together with a voucher for the amount of the grant due.

The remarks of the Principal on the quarterly return and of yourself on the vouchers relative to the fourteen pupils who were allowed home for the summer holidays and who did not return during the September quarter owing to an outbreak of measles on the reserve are noted and the grant has been allowed the school for these pupils in full for the above quarter. The grant is calculated and paid on an average attendance of 44.32 pupils and amounts to $1446.40, a cheque for which is being sent.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 27, 1921.

Reverend Sir,

The September quarter return of the Kuper Island Industrial School is being paid on an average attendance of 85 pupils and amounts to $3,612.50. From this amount the Department is deducting $33.08 for gasoline supplied your school. A cheque for the balance, $3,579.42, has been forwarded.

Your obedient servant

Indian Industrial School,
Kuper Island,
B. C.
Dear Sir:-

I hereby acknowledge receipt of official cheque No.1968 to the value of $3579.42.

My regular charges against the Department were $3612.50.

Had I some outstanding debts or was the balance kept for some other reason?

Yours obediently,

(Signed) Jos. Geurts,
Principal.

Duncan, B. C.
Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith copy of letter today received from Reverend Father Geurts, Principal of Kuper Island Industrial School, in regard to official cheque No.1968 for $3579.42.

Will you please advise me on the matter.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Alfred H. Lomas,
Indian Agent.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary, Dept. Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
OTTAWA, Nov. 9th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing a copy of a letter received from the principal of the Kuper Island Industrial School, with reference to the cheque sent him in payment of the grant for the quarter ending September 30th, last.

In reply I beg to say that the grant for the September quarter was paid on an average attendance of 56, and amounted to $3612.50. From this amount, the Department deducted $33.08 to cover an account for gasoline bought for this institution. The balance, therefore, due was $3579.42, and a cheque for that amount was sent.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Alfred H. Lomas, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.

Re: Kuper Island Residential School,

Roman Catholic.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit herewith report of my examination of the books of the Kuper Island Residential School.

Kuper Island is situated opposite Chemainus B.C., about 4 miles distant. I arrived at the School in the late afternoon of June 19 and completed my inspection at noon of the 21, proceeding by train in the afternoon to the Indian Agency Office at Duncan, to complete my report.

Records available for examination included Cash Book, Bank Pass Book, cancelled cheques and an incomplete set of vouchers. The books are kept by the Principal, Father Geurts, and his system of recording transactions made a complete examination impossible. The following is a brief outline of his methods.

Two accounts, one a Savings and the other a Current Account, are maintained in the Canadian Bank Of Commerce, Chemainus, each in the name Rev. Joseph Geurts. Departmental cheques covering the Per Capita Grant were deposited in the Savings Account in order to draw interest, Father Geurts explained. The Cash Book, however, did not show that the School received any credit for interest.

The balance on deposit at May 31, was $367.06 which included School and private funds.

The Current Account was started by deposit of a cheque drawn on the Savings Account and thereafter was replenished as required by transfers of $1000.00 from the Savings Account. Cheques drawn on the Current Account included those issued covering payments of School expenditure and many more which the Principal explained were not connected with the School. I would suggest here that the Department might consider the advisability of having the Current Account in the name of the School in place of in Father Geurt's name in the Bank.

The revenue entries in the Cash Book included Departmental cheques for the Per Capita Grant and salary of the Manuel Training Instructor, with sundry amounts which Father Geurts stated was the correct revenue of the School. Expenditure entries were - Cheques issued for School expenditure, cash expended and entries made quarterly of $1500.00 for salaries of staff. Cheques were not issued for salaries and there was no supporting vouchers for the entries, Father Geurts stating payments were made in cash or from private funds. Cash was obtained from the cashing of cheques for salary of the Manuel Training Instructor, from amounts received from Indians and others to be forwarded and which were forwarded by

N.C. Allen Esq.,
Representative Of The Treasury,
Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6456, file 885-3, part 1)
cheque on the Current Account, and sundry amounts received as revenue.

From the above it will be noted that Father Geurts never tried to balance the Bank Account with the Cash Book. His theory was to have all Receipts and Expenditures correctly entered in the Cash Book and have sufficient funds in the Current Account.

As a test audit of the Cash Book for the fiscal year 1933-34, I examined the entries for receipts, scrutinized all entries of expenditure comparing many with the accounts and cancelled cheques and tested all the additions. For the period April 1, 1934, to May 31, 1935, I examined in detail all receipts and expenditures and checked all additions. All entries appear correct in so far as I was able to verify.

In order to balance the Bank Pass Book with the Cash Book as at May 31, the following statement was prepared:

Balance as per Bank Book May 31-1935 $1,130.56

Balance as per Bank Pass Book (Current Acc't.) $570.92
Less Unpresented Cheque 16.10
Amount to be transferred from Savings Acc't. 554.82
Amount to be transferred from Savings Acc't. 575.74

$1,130.56 $1,130.56

This statement was embodied in a memorandum to Father Geurts outlining the bookkeeping procedure to be followed in the future, copy of memorandum attached herewith as Exhibit A.

After examination of the Cash Book a statement of Receipts and Expenditures for the Fiscal Year ending March 31, 1935, statement #1, was prepared. Receipts are normal and would not appear to call for special comment.

Expenditure shown under the various headings in statement #1 is detailed under sub-headings in statement #2.

For food $3,328.07 was expended which is high when the amount of foodstuffs grown on the farm, shown later in this report, is considered.

The cost of Phone, Fuel and Light was $859.32. Phone expenditure of $13.94 is light as the telephone is on the pay-phone basis, there being no service charge. The total expenditure for gas and oil amounted to $496.88 of which it was estimated $120.00 worth was used in the motor boat and is shown under the heading Transportation.

Included in the total expenditure of $1,491.16 for Farm and Garden is $1,265.29 for feed which appears high considering the amount of feed grown on the farm.

Statement #3 shows costs of operations for the year ending March 31, 1935, based on the actual expenditure of $15,108.49 as Father Geurts would not attempt to estimate the value of produce from the farm consumed in the School. The average attendance was 99.

Information re Farm

The farm consists of 75 acres of which 50 are cultivated. Crop figures for 1934 are as follows:

Field Crops
May 26 tons, Green Feed 10 tons, Mangles 18 tons, White Carrots 10 tons.

Garden Crop
Potatoes 8 tons, Tomatoes 3 tons, Red Carrots 2 tons, Cabbage 300 head and considerable crop of beans, peas, celery, asparagus, corn & onions.

Milk
Average 250 lbs., per day

Butter
All that is required.

Eggs
Average 75 per day.
GENERAL

I wish to acknowledge the courtesies of Father Geurts who appears ready to co-operate with the Department and was very willing to adopt any bookkeeping procedure which would assist in future audits and be in line with Departmental requirements.

Ottawa, July 13, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return the June quarter return of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School.

I note from the enclosed that the children left for holidays on June 27. You should however have requested 91 days' grant for those pupils who were in regular attendance during the whole quarter. This means that four (4) days of the holiday grant was taken during the June quarter and will leave the balance of 58 days' holidays. When preparing the September quarter return, grant for the full quarter should be requested for all pupils who were in residence at the time the holidays started and who returned to the school by August 27. For any pupil who does not return by August 27 grant should be requested on the September quarter return for the actual number of days in residence during September plus 58 days - the balance of the holiday leave. As requested in the first part of this letter, you should revise the June quarter return and send it back for payment of the grant.

To assist you in your financing, a cheque for $2,000, being part payment on the June quarter return, is being forwarded. The balance will be paid when the return is properly completed.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. John Camirand,
Principal,
Kuper Island Residential School,
Kuper Island, via Chemainus, B. C.

April 14/40

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir,

Kindly notice in the financial statement that salaries for the fiscal year 39-40 amount to $4,575.00 instead of the usual $6,000.00 dollars. My salary and part of that of my assistant has not be paid due to the fact that I have used that money to defray expenses for food, etc., during approximately two months when I first came in charge and when I brought the school attendance from forty children to ninety, having only the amount of a previous small grant to meet expenses. This together with the unusual conditions in which the school happened to be which forced me to give my attention to a score of other matters than finance is the reason why I had to forgo payment of my salary. This however I may easily redeem with time.

Sorry that my report is a little late, I am

Yours truly

Rev John Cameron

Ottawa, July 23, 1946.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to the June Quarter Return of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, I can not understand why you only ask grant for eighty-nine days in the June quarter. Possibly, the reason for doing so was that the school closed two or three days before the end of June. Please make the necessary changes and send the return back to us so that the grant may be paid.

Dear Sir,

The New England Company being convinced by more than sixty years experience of the benefits which their Institution at Brantford, Ontario has conferred upon the Indian races of British North America that there is no more effectual mode of Christianizing and civilizing the natives than by training their children in Industrial Schools of all similar kind, and believing that the Comp...
any Mission Station at Rupert Island, British Columbia, which has been established for more than ten years, affords exceptional advantages for the successful management of an industrial boarding school for the children of the comparatively neglected Indians of that Province. I have been instructed to enquire whether, in the event of the Company being willing to undertake the entire management of such an institution, and to provide such additional funds as may be required for its maintenance, the Dominion Government would be prepared to erect a suitable building on the Company's land for the accommodation of not less than thirty children and the necessary staff of teachers, and would also make a yearly capitation grant towards its support, proportionate to the peculiar circumstances of the case, as provided.
similar institutions in the Province of Athabasca and elsewhere.

I may mention that the proposal has the cordial support of the Anglican Bishop of Columbia, the local Superintendent of Indians, and many other persons well acquainted with the needs of the Red-men, and that but for an unfortunate misunderstanding as to the amount of financial support which the Company would receive from the Government, the scheme would probably have been carried out several years ago, when first recommended by their missionary, the Rev. Mr. Roberts.

I am also instructed to say that the Company have received private information that the Roman Catholic community are likely to relinquish their charge of the Industrial school at Telegraph Bay, Rupert Island, and that, in any such event, they would be prepared to undertake the management of this School, subject to an adequate capitation.
grant being provided, thus avoiding the necessity for a new building.

As the Company will be holding their annual general meeting on the 11th May, when full consideration could most advantageously be given to any proposals which the Dominion Government may be pleased to make on the subject, the favour of your reply within the next three months will greatly oblige.

I am, dear Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Walter C. Murray

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that today at 13:30 P.M. fire was discovered in the boys' building by one of our female teachers who happened to enter into the play hall. At this time I was with Mr. Foreman and the two boys in the furthest end of the hall. As soon as the alarm bell sounded the alarm, everyone ran for the buildings as quick as possible, and in a few minutes the fire brigade was in full activity. When we arrived at the chimney building, the play hall and school rooms were full of smoke, and in order to locate the seat of the fire, the Foreman had to tear off the frame of the door leading to the school room and part of the frame on which the chimney is built; as far as the eye could see, quite apparent that the fire was caused through a defective chimney. One of the four bricks in which the chimney flue is built, and the chimney inside the main frame was totally charred, there had been no fire in the stove since Saturday evening, thus the fire must have originated last night.

As the fire was burning close to the ceiling and on inside of the wall, it was rather a difficult matter to subdue it, however after half an hour, liberty was had the fire under control.

The damage to the building is very slight, but the chimney will have to be secured against future danger before any fire can be made in the school rooms.

I have the honour to inform you that the following provision for protection against fire is made at this Institution. The teachers and boys are drilled in the proper use of fire-tubes and buckets. At the call of the fire bell two boys have charge of connecting hose to hydrant, one boy is ordered to produce an axe or crowbar, four big boys are required to get the ladder in position and the smaller boys are drilled in passing the water buckets from one to another.

There are four hydrants outside, three hose can be attached to, one in the rear of the boys' building, one at the kitchen, one in front of the main building and one at the corner of the girls' home. The buckets stand outside in a row underneath the staircase leading to the girls' dormitory and in close proximity to the water so that there is no necessity of keeping them full of water. The stream of water running between the buildings is kept full to the top so that in case of emergency any boy can fill a bucket with ease and dispatch. There are four sets of ladders and three movable ladders which hang alongside the buildings within easy reach.

The flues and chimneys are regularly cleaned and the registers and stoves are frequently examined.

With regard to the fire-proof lights that there is only about half of it left and what is left is nearly worn out. In my last report (July 2nd 1895) I made application for 100 ft. 2 inch fire hose, price about $15.00.

One day's new buckets and one set of ladder hooks for the roof of the new girls' home would also be required for protection against fire; at the present time we have only twelve buckets available.

I have the honour to be,

A.W. Sorrell, Esq.
Indian Superintendent
Victoria

Yours obediently,

G. Demers,

Sir,

In reply to your circular of the 11th inst., I beg to report that I have just visited the Kuper Industrial Schools, and find that with the exception of the want of more fire buckets and hose every precaution is taken to avoid fire.

The floors and chimneys are regularly cleaned and the tanks kept full. There is however a want of buckets as those in use are not being used for other purposes, such as when scrubbing the floors is going on.

On the upper floors there are hydrants to which the hose can be attached, but the buckets should be kept full for fear of a failure in the supply of water.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Once more I am coming to remind you of our visit to our school. Among the many improvements you encouraged me to make, there was a gymnasium for the boys; it was to be built out of the material of the old school. You promised to pay for the new material required, such as shingles and flooring. After your return to Ottawa in a letter I received from Mr. McLean, dated July 28th, 1916, this item is mentioned among those you authorised.

We could not possibly build the gymnasium last winter on account of a lot of other work more urgent yet, but now it is almost completed. It is a building 76' x 33', with an 18' ceiling. The floor of the gymnasium proper is 60' x 33'. The other 16' are occupied by two rooms, a dressing room and a toilet room. Above these there is a gallery 16' x 33' for the pupils who would not be taking part in the game or drill going on in the hall. It is situated on the hill near the boys' playground at a distance of 150 from the school.

On account of the number of windows in the old school building a lot of the old boards were wasted, being too short to be of any use. We have enough rustic, but had to get some new ship-lap. The old school being plastered, for the inside finishing of the gymnasium I had to get some V joint. I took the cheapest No. 4 V joint will go up to the windows, above them and on the ceiling we will use ship-lap. I enclose herewith the bills in triplicate.

If you need any more information I will give it to you personally. I have been applying for a holiday during which I intend to visit my brother in Ottawa, and naturally I will profit by the occasion to pay you my respects. I expect to be in Ottawa by the end of the month.

Au revoir.

Yours obediently,

Dear Mr. Scott,

In the beginning of this new year I have to come and beg you for quite a few favors. But first of all, allow me to thank you for the repairs done to our wharf. The work will be finished in a couple of days. It has been well and expeditiously done. All the inconveniences we had to put up with for a whole year are at an end now. And none too soon, because in a couple of weeks I will have to get in a supply of coal. The prices, right at the mine, have advanced more than a dollar per ton. If I had had a wharf, I would have saved that, because I would have got my supply before the prices advanced. Our heating plant and our steam laundry consume 100 tons of coal in the year, notwithstanding the nice mild weather. The violets have been blooming the whole winter.

I said I came to beg a few favors, not for me, but for the school. Besides the medicines that Sister Superior would like to get, I need about $30.00 worth of trees and shrubs, and I need also paint, and shingle stain for our boys' gymnasium. This building is finished now. Everybody says it is a beautiful hall, I am sure, you will like it. But the old lumber we used needs painting very badly.
I cannot tell you exactly how much it is going to cost, because it is hard to say how much paint this old lumber is going to take. But I will get the paint direct from the factory, Brit. N. America Paint Co., Victoria, and I will send you the bills, if you allow. Besides I absolutely need to put up 350 rods of wire fence, on both sides of the road (going to the Indian village) crossing our fields, around a new garden near the school, and one part of the boundary fence which is in very bad shape, through which the Indian cattle come and spoil our crops. This wire fence with necessary gates will cost $356.50 (three hundred and fifty six dollars, 50¢), viz., 350 rods of No 9 wire fence 8 bars 43" * 77¢ per rod; 4 large gates 12 ft. x 48" * $11.00, and two small gates 4 ft. x 48" * 5.00. I enclose two letters quoting prices. We have the necessary cedar posts for the fences, and naturally we will do all the work ourselves.

At your visit to the school this summer, you will be surprised at all the work that has been done here since your last visit. Although there is a lot yet to be done, we are trying to join the agreeable to the useful "Utile dulce", so as to beautify the surroundings of our magnificent school.

With best wishes and kind regards,

I beg to remain,

Yours obediently,

Dear Mr. Scott,

Whilst passing through Ottawa last fall, I spoke to you about the pipes of the kitchen sinks getting blocked up with grease very frequently, and causing a lot of inconvenience. You called for Mr. Ogilvie, and we discussed what would be best to do. I suggested to either get a "Restaurant grease trap", or to make a separate sewer for those sinks leading the greasy water directly to the sea, instead of through the main sewer. Before leaving you allowed me to have the grease trap installed, in case I would think it would work satisfactorily, after investigation. As soon as I came back I spoke the matter over with the man who had done all the plumbing in the house. He told me then that he had just been installing one at the Resthaven Convalescent home for returned soldiers, I thought that was sufficient proof that it was all it was claimed to be, and I gave Mr. Holt order to get one for us. It took all this time to get the trap here from the East. When I heard I was going to leave I asked the plumber to come at once and install it, so I could send in the bill myself. We did away with quite a length of 2" pipe and connected the trap directly with the 4" sewer, this required quite a bit of labor, but it was the only way one could expect satisfactory results. Thanking you for this last service rendered.

I beg to inform you that some time ago the Reverend Principal of the Epper Island School telephoned me stating that the boiler for the laundry at the school was leaking and asked me to send up a man to repair it. I therefore informed the firm of Messrs. Thacker & Holt, who did all the plumbing and made all the boiler connections at the school when it was built, and Mr. Holt went up the next day. He has reported that in his opinion the boiler will need re-tubing throughout with seventy-two tubes, four feet long and two inches in diameter. He reported that upon going to the school he found that one of the tubes was leaking and he sent to Victoria and had a new one sent up, which he replaced. Upon putting 80 pounds steam pressure on the boiler a second tube blew out. This he plugged at both ends and then turned on 75 pounds of steam pressure when a third tube burst. He then returned to Victoria realizing that nothing could be done at present. He estimates the cost of re-tubing will be $375.00. The expense already entailed in the repairs amount to approximately $70.00. Rev. Father Guertz, the Principal, thought as this is an extraordinary expenditure the Department should bear the same. The boiler, in the meantime, was out of use. I have laid this matter before Mr. Scott and he has authorized the work to be done.

At the time of my visit to this school this summer, the following matters were brought to my attention: Land is badly needed - there are 75 acres at present. Mr. Agent Lomas would like something done in an effort to quiet the older Indians of the band, who insist that they were to have been paid for this property. Fifty acres to the east of the school site is reserve land, not settled and might be acquired.

Grapes, walnuts, fruits of all kinds, all vegetables and some of the potatoes are raised. They have 7 milch cows and 3 horses, but not enough land to raise beef. Water supply and acetylene lighting systems - in good condition. They have enough water to irrigate all of the 50 acres that are cultivated, from the reservoir.

I found here the best gymnasium at any Indian school in Canada. There is a spectators' balcony, dressing rooms, lavatories and playrooms - all in the gymnasium building. There is a splendid Band here; they need a few more instruments at this time. They have splendid manual training equipment, but no instructor. Mr. Cairne suggests a Government manual training instructor to travel among the 5 or 6 residential schools on the mainland.

The barn is fairly adequate - the hennery and piggery are good - excellent laundry equipment - good bakery and dairy - heating O.K. The bake oven needs repairs and they will write about this. I noticed in the pig pen a splendid swing swivel wall over the trough.
Dear Sir:

So far we have already 200 bushels of oats in the barn and we expect about 150 more from this year's crop. Three hundred of these could be used as pigs' feed if only they were ground.

But isolated as we are, to have this done or to have them exchanged for crushed oats would cost us about $10.00 a ton for transportation.

Therefore I hereby apply for a 6½" grinder with bagger attachment to be bought from Mark Dumond who has given the lowest quotation: grinder $62.00, bagger attachment $18.00.

Trusting the Department will favorably consider this request,

I beg to remain, Dear Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

I have to inform you that on the 9th instant I had a visit from the Rev. Father A. Murphy, Principal of the Kuper Island School, with regard to the drain pipes from the sinks to the sewer which continually become blocked up with grease, the traps at the sinks not retaining the grease as they should. Various methods have been tried to overcome this trouble, but are not effective. Different acids and lye have been poured down the sinks to cut the grease, but this has resulted in turning it into a solid soapy substance, and the grease-pan under the main sink in the boys' dining room is now almost totally blocked up, with a result that when the water is turned on in the shower-bath room this becomes flooded with greasy water etc., and the Rev. Father was afraid that an epidemic of Typhoid Fever might result unless something was done to keep these pipes permanently open.

Being something of a mechanic himself, he turned the garden hose into the pipe and this cleared the way to a limited extent, but he requested that he be supplied with 150 feet of 1 inch vulcanized hose with the proper attachments which could be connected with the boiler and this drain pipe cleared out regularly by steam pressure.

Before submitting this proposal to you, I interviewed Messrs. Thacker & Holt, Plumbing and Heating Contractors, of this city, who installed all the plumbing in this building, and they informed me that they are of the opinion that the scheme suggested by Father Murphy, if applied properly, will accomplish its purpose.

The price of vulcanized hose given me by the Rubber Companies is $1.25 per foot less 50% and 10%. Couplings are $2.25 each less 10%. I have not been able to obtain a price for the attachment to the boiler and clean-out, but estimate they would not be over $7.00. The total cost of the connection pipes and nozzles would approximate $104.00.

I shall be pleased to know if you will authorise this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn,
Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA, March 1st, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo, regarding the difficulty experienced at the Kuper Island Industrial School owing to the drain pipes from the sinks to the sewer becoming blocked up with grease, etc.

In reply I beg to say that your request for authority to purchase 150 feet of 1½" vulcanized hose with the proper attachments, which could be connected to the boiler and the drain pipes cleared by steam pressure, is approved. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase of the above quantity of vulcanized hose, and the necessary attachments. The cost should not exceed your estimate of approximately $104.00. It will be necessary, if possible, to obtain competitive prices for the supplying of the above material, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. Properly certified vouchers should be forwarded, with an abstract of the prices received.

We hope that the method suggested by the Principal and yourself of using the hose to carry hot steam from the boiler will be satisfactory in overcoming the difficulty now experienced by the blocking up of the drain pipes.

Your obedient servant,

My dear Sir:

It gives me pleasure to tell you that I made the official visitation of our branch house in Kuper Island from January 8th to 11th, and, as a result, I submit the following for your kind consideration:

1. The house was most comfortably heated, and the staff of Sisters provided with all that is necessary as regards food and general supplies.

2. The Principal, Reverend Father Murphy, is a good provider, and is kind and genial to all.

3. As was pointed out to you when visiting the School, no provision was made for lavatory convenience on the second story. If I have been rightly informed, you suggested that the staircase leading to the Girls' Recreation Room might easily be removed, and the space utilized for that purpose. I do not know if you authorized this to be done, or if you simply mentioned the possibility of its being done. However, I would request you to kindly take up this matter with the Agent, or with Reverend Father Murphy, and advise them that this should be no longer delayed. This flat contains the living room, the dining-room and the class-room, and not a drop of water is available. Much valuable time is lost, and energy wasted by going up and down stairs so frequently. A sink and a lavatory there would be, not only a great boon, but an absolute necessity. Knowing your intentions as regards the comfort and convenience of the Sisters, I feel that you will not hesitate to recommend that the work be done immediately.

Sister Mary Albert is still in Hospital, but is gradually improving. I doubt that she will ever be able to return to Kuper Island.

Thanking you for all past kindness,

I am, dear Sir,

Very sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

The writer was at Kuper Island Indian School estimating the proposed new Bath rooms and was asked by Father Murphy to suggest a scheme to improve the condition of the sink wastes.

These waste pipes from the kitchen sinks are continually choking up owing to the long distance they have to travel under cold concrete which causes the grease to congeal in the pipes, necessitating continually blowing them out with steam.

When this job was originally installed it was equipped with a cast iron grease trap. This trap was replaced some years ago with a water-cooled grease trap which improved matters somewhat. Later the Department supplied a long steam hose to blow out the grease. This last arrangement has proved a great help, not only to the sink wastes but to all the other drains on the job.

The writer would suggest that the sinks be disconnected from the rest of the plumbing, carried through outside wall and connected to a specially constructed concrete grease trap, a sketch of which we submit. This trap is one we have used successfully in large hotels and schools, the cover is movable and the grease can be removed from time to time; the waste is then carried on to the bank about 60 feet from the building in 4" Vitrified pipe and then distributed in 4" field tile. We estimate the cost of this work will amount to $150.00.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) THACKER & HOLT,
per Geo. Holt.

Sir,

I have the honor to apply to you on behalf of the Principal of the Kuper Island Industrial School for an expenditure of approximately $300 for the purchase of a new gasoline pump for use in that school. The same is a matter of immediate necessity; the original pump was discarded last year being worn beyond repair. Rev. Father Murphy, the Principal, purchasing a small gas pump on sale, the oil one from proceeds of his per capita grant, this new has been found to have insufficient power.

For your information I should like to point out that the school authorities have been put to a great expense during the past year with the plumbing at the school. It appears that the water pipes were set in the concrete foundations at time of construction, trouble arose last fall and after considerable trouble and expense it was found that one wing of the building had sunk several inches, with the result that the pipes in that section became severed.

In the same way I find that the acetylene lighting system has become faulty through the settling of the building and at times the fumes of the gas is found throughout the building. A leakage at different points is apparent, which is borne out by the fact that over a ton more carbide was used during the past winter than in previous ones. I would therefore ask that the Department give their very serious consideration as to a change of the lighting system of the school to electricity. I need not point out the obvious danger of a sudden great leakage of this gas, through the further sinking of the building, especially in view of the fact that practically a hundred children live in the building.

In conversation with the Reverend Father Murphy he rightly explains that with the many improvements and repairs that have been carried out during the past year, through the changing of the water pipes etc., that he cannot in any way consider the purchase of pumps, or change in lighting system. I would most respectfully request that these matters be given consideration.

Your obedient servant,

(Alfred H. Lomas)
Indian Agent.

Electric light needs no advocate. Everyone knows the convenience, cleanliness, safety and comfort of this system of lighting, although only those who have used it fully appreciate its advantages.

Good lighting is not the only convenience which a private installation will give you, for many daily tasks in the household and on the farm may be done, cheaply and cleanly, by means of the electric current, and with great saving of labour. Such as:

- Cooking
- Heating of Houses
- Carpet Sweeping and Beating
- Table Heaters
- Ironing
- Vacuum Cleaning
- Pumping Water
- Heating Water in any part of the house
- Milking
- Dairy Work

The best method of obtaining the electric current, when out of reach of the city mains, is the question on which many are seeking information. The chief considerations in any isolated electric plant are: that it shall not be too costly to install; that the light shall be always available without any trouble; that it shall be easy and cheap to maintain.

THE NECESSARY PLANT.

In all cases an engine is used to drive a dynamo which generates the electric current used in the lamps and elsewhere.
It is, however, not always convenient to run the engine when an odd light or two are wanted in a hurry, and therefore storage batteries are added to the plant to meet this requirement.

The storage batteries are charged by the engine and dynamo, and, as their name implies, they store the current until required. They may be used by themselves to supply any number of lights, but this convenience has to be paid for, as you do not get as much out of a battery as you have to put into it to keep it charged; it is, therefore, uneconomical to use the battery to supply a large number of lights.

When the lights are on at night, and the engine and dynamo are running full power, the plant is working most economically, but when the engine is running to supply only a few lights it is not working nearly so efficiently; in fact, it is cheaper to use the storage battery only in this case.

From the above we learn that the most economical method of operation is:

- To use the battery to supply a few lights only (say, quarter of the total);
- To run the engine when more lights are wanted;
- To charge the battery from the engine and dynamo when convenient.

It will be obvious that, while it is simple enough to switch on a few lights from the battery, it becomes very inconvenient to be continually counting the number actually on throughout the house; and when they exceed so many, to go out to the engine room and start up the engine and dynamo, and, similarly, stop it again when the extra lights are put out. This would mean constant attendance in the engine room.

The LISTER-BRUSTON Patent Automatic Lighting and Power Plants have been specially designed to do exactly what has been stated above, BY THEMSELVES AND WITHOUT ATTENTION. Any number of lights may be switched on at any time of the day or night, the plant starting and stopping itself as occasion demands, only a very occasional special run being required.
The LISTER-BRUSTON Plant therefore gives the greatest possible economy in running costs, and light is available at any time—by merely switching on.

Economy and simplicity of maintenance—because, being automatic, the engine starts itself after a certain number of lights are switched on, gives you the light and at the same time puts current into the battery, so never allowing it to run down, and stops itself when you have finished. All you are asked to do in the way of maintenance is to keep it clean, and put fuel and oil in the engine when required.

**NOTHING COULD BE MORE SIMPLE.**

The plant may be used during the daytime for doing other work, such as pumping water, operating dairy and domestic appliances.

The LISTER-BRUSTON system is eminently suitable, and has been very extensively adopted, for both large and small country house work at home and bungalows abroad, institutions, churches, hotels, factories and small towns.

LISTER-BRUSTON were the originators of Automatic Lighting and Power Plants (the first automatic sets being made in 1907), since when the system has not only been applied to lighting and cooking in country houses, but also the lighting of towns, and for emergency lighting and wireless power on board ship.

The highly efficient LISTER engine provides the motive power in LISTER-BRUSTON plants. The soundness of design and the excellent quality of the workmanship put into these engines is well-known to all users throughout the world. They operate at a comparatively slow speed, with freedom from wear and tear, and in consequence the working parts have a greatly increased life over the high speed sets sometimes met with.
The System as applied to Town Lighting

The essential requirement of a public supply for a small town is that there shall be a twenty-four hour service. The difficulties which have hitherto been experienced in connection with supplies are: That the increased efficiency of the modern lamps in use results in a decreased revenue to the supply companies; labour costs are very high; and a considerable amount of capital is sunk in a larger plant in anticipation of a future demand.

The LISTER-BRUSTON Parallel Working System is specially adaptable for this class of work for the following reasons:

The initial cost is lower because it is only in proportion to the immediate requirements of the town or village. Additional sets may be added from time to time as the demand for current grows, the additional plants being interconnected in such a manner that they start and stop themselves automatically when the load is increased or diminished as the case may be—thus maintaining the HIGHEST POSSIBLE EFFICIENCY AT ALL LOADS.
The System as applied to Town Lighting—Continued.

Labour costs are reduced because a power station equipped with these plants does not need constant attendance. One operator can visit a number of stations every day to see to fuel and oil requirements and do any cleaning necessary.

The saving in working costs due to less labour employed and less interest on capital more than balances the diminished revenue on account of consumers using the modern high efficiency lamps, and puts the financial side of any electricity undertaking on a sound basis.

The word "automatic" is frequently associated with a complicated mechanism. Such, however is not the case with the LISTER-BRUSTON system, which, if anything, is more simple than ordinary hand-operated plants.

Automatic working has been proved to be more reliable than manual attention. As an instance we would point out that the majority of electric lifts are worked automatically; also the safety of millions of people on the Underground Railways of London depends upon automatic signalling.
Some Advantages of the Lister-Bruston Automatic System

AUTOMATIC operation. The plant gives a continuous service of light, the engine starting and stopping itself when necessary without anyone going to the engine room. The only attention required is to keep it supplied with fuel, oil and water, and in a reasonably clean condition, and a very occasional special run.

Lower first cost, owing to the necessity of a battery of only a fourth or fifth the size of the battery required if all the load were taken from it, as in non-automatic plants.

The system is such that, although the capacity of the battery is comparatively small, it is kept in practically fully charged condition, and thus, in the event of a failure of the engine, the battery is capable of supplying a normal load for some time. The time limit reverse current circuit breaker which is fitted on the switchboard cuts the dynamo off from the battery should the engine fail to start within a given time, or fail through lack of fuel, etc.; thus protecting the battery from discharging itself by motoring the dynamo for long periods.

With an ordinary hand-operated accumulator system the usual practice is to run the engine only when the battery is discharged and requires charging up, with the result that
Some Advantages of the LISTER-BRUSTON Automatic System—Continued

although a larger storage battery may be installed, only a small capacity is available in case of a breakdown.

Economical running by saving battery losses and running direct from the dynamo, unless only a few lights are in use.

The LISTER-BRUSTON Automatic Generating System is the simplest, most economical and efficient means of providing electric light and power.

The LISTER-BRUSTON Plant, being self-contained, and not fixed to the floor, can be easily moved from place to place; consequently it becomes a tenant's fixture, and may be moved from one house to another at the end of the tenancy.

Ordinary Town Gas may be used instead of Petrol to drive engine if preferred.

Owing to the efficient and automatic arrangement for oiling the engine, the cost of lubrication with the LISTER - BRUSTON system is far less than with the other systems.

Electric light from the LISTER-BRUSTON Automatic Plant requires less attention than Acetylene or Petrol Gas Light. It does not vitiate the air or give off poisonous fumes, consequently it is much healthier. There is no smoke, and it does not, therefore, spoil decorations.
The Selection of the Best Type of Plant

THE satisfactory operation of the plant depends, to a great extent, upon the most suitable size of plant being installed.

The services of one of our engineers are always at the disposal of intending purchasers, to give any assistance that may be required in the general arrangement, and amount and disposition of lighting, and to recommend the most suitable plant to instal.

For small installations where lighting only is required, together with, say, small domestic appliances such as vacuum cleaner, 55 volts will be found the most suitable. If, however, it is desired to use any heating appliances, small motors, etc., 110 volts would be preferable.

As a result of experience it is usually found that not more than two-thirds of the lighting capacity requirements of a house are used at any one time, and a plant selected for this load will be found to give the best results.

ARRANGEMENT. In the smaller sizes the drive is by belt from the engine flywheel to the dynamo. ENGINE. LISTER Slow Speed Vertical Engine of standard construction, and usual excellent finish, with extra heavy flywheels, crowned in belt driven sets, giving steady running at all loads and speeds. Designed for working long periods without

In large installations, especially country mansions, where during a period of the year a light load only is required, the LISTER-BRUSTON parallel system of working is installed. In some instances two plants of equal size are employed, interconnected in such a manner that when the load is within the capacity of one set, one set only is running. Immediately the load is increased to beyond the capacity of No. 1 set, the second automatically steps into operation and runs in parallel. Likewise when the load is reduced the plants automatically cut themselves out. Further, should one of the sets fail through any cause, the second automatically steps into operation and takes over the load.

In instances where it is considered advisable the two sets may be unequal, for instance a 4 kw. and 8 kw. set. The operation of unequal sized plants is as follows:

On light load the 4 kw. set starts. When the load is increased to beyond the capacity of 4 kw., the 8 kw. plant automatically starts up and the 4 kw. stops. Upon the load being further increased to beyond the capacity of the 8 kw. set, the 4 kw. set again comes into operation.

The Lister-Bruston Service at Sea

Self-Starting Self-Testing Self-Stopping

EMERGENCY PLANTS.

(Extract from The Steamship, January, 1918).

What are the essential features of genuine emergency electrical generating sets as applied to a ship?

(1) It must be ready to start INSTANTLY the main supply fails.
(2) It must always be in good running order and should require little attention.
(3) It should be independent of any outside agency to start it, which might be affected by confusion due to a collision or other accident.
(4) It should be so arranged that the engineer or other authorised person could easily test it at any time and quickly ascertain if it is in working order.

The LISTER-BRUSTON set meets all these requirements, viz.—
(1) The instant that the main supply fails from any cause, the plant automatically starts up and supplies current to the wireless apparatus and that portion of the ship's lighting which has previously been arranged for. The resumption of main supply will stop the plant.
The Lister-Bruston Service at Sea—Continued.

(2) The plant is self-testing. Owing to the action of a time switch it will start up automatically at a given time every day and run for a given time. Tell-tale lamps are fitted where required, which will indicate if the plant is out of order. These lamps may be fitted in the engineer's cabin, or wireless operator's cabin, or elsewhere. This regular running will keep the plant in good condition, so that it is always ready for the emergency. The amount of attention required is reduced to a minimum.

(3) The failure of the main supply starts the plant, therefore the starting is independent of any outside agency which might be affected by confusion due to accident or attack.

(4) Testing switches can be placed where desired, so that by simply operating a small tumbler switch the plant will start at any time.

The LISTER-BRUSTON plant, therefore, meets all requirements that can possibly be desired to give a really efficient plant.

At an inquiry into the loss of a ship during the Great War, it was given in evidence that the operator tried to send a wireless call for help, but it could not be done owing to a second explosion which occurred in the engine-room having stopped the dynamo and left the ship without any current. An auxiliary set which takes fifteen or twenty minutes to start cannot be regarded as an efficient emergency set, as during that period the ship would...
The Lister-Bruston Service at Sea—Continued.

be in darkness and no wireless signals could be sent out, and fifteen or twenty valuable minutes would be lost, so that the benefits conferred by such a system as the LISTER-BRUSTON are obvious.

Not only is this system applicable to steamships, but if installed on sailing ships would add comfort by supplying electric light, and safety by adding wireless. It would also be a good investment, as it would enable a sailing ship to signal her arrival when, say, 100 miles from port, which would often facilitate arrangements for reception of cargo; or even if the owners wished to transfer the cargo to another port wireless would save delay and, consequently, money. Standard sets can now be supplied from 1 kw. to 15 kw., and larger sizes to order.

During the War many instances occurred of loss of life due to vessels being plunged into darkness at the time of collision or accident, and it was mentioned at the official enquiries which were held afterwards “that loss of life and valuable time were wasted owing to the darkness.”

We have installed S.O.S. Emergency Sets on naval vessels during the War and the following is an extract of letter received from the Chief Engineer of one vessel:

“Up to the time of writing we have had a good number of runs off the plant and all has, up to now, gone off splendidly and without falter.”

A subsequent letter from the Engineer states the following:

“The H.M.S. (censored) is no more. On (censored) it was torpedoed and the engine room flooded in a few seconds. The LISTER-BRUSTON Automatic Emergency Set, however, came into operation and maintained the supply to the vessel and continued to supply until the plant was submerged.”

WATER SERVICE.

One of the most important questions which has to be dealt with is the provision of a water supply, as only in very few instances is the public water supply available, and although hitherto the pumping has been undertaken either by manual labour or horse, when a LISTER-BRUSTON Plant is installed it can be adapted to do this work.

In instances where it is practicable to fix a pump in the engine room, we recommend that it is driven from there on the electric light engine itself, as shown on page 20.

Should it not be possible to do the pumping it is only necessary to turn on a switch on the LISTER-BRUSTON switchboard, which will start up the engine, and, by means of suitable belt striking gear, a belt on the pump can be moved on to the fixed pulley, when the pump will immediately commence to do its work.

DEEP WELL PUMPS.

Should the distance from the ground level to the water exceed 15 feet it will be necessary to install a deep well pattern pump.

To enable us to quote for these, the following particulars are necessary:

1. Type and diameter of well.
2. Depth to bottom of well.
3. Level of water below ground level.
4. Can LISTER-BRUSTON plant be placed near well to enable pump to be driven by belt from engine.
5. Distance of Plant from well.
6. Height and distance to which water has to be pumped.
7. Approximate quantity of water required, per hour or per day.
8. Maximum variation of depth of water in well due to season of year.
The LISTER-BRUSTON Plant in the Country House—Continued.

ELECTRICALLY DRIVEN PUMPS.

In instances where the well is too far from the electric light plant to permit of its being driven from the engine itself, it will be necessary to install electrically driven pumps.

When the pump is driven by an electric motor, whether in the engine room or some distance away, its operation may be automatically controlled by means of a float in the water supply tank, thus:

When the water level in the tank has dropped to about one-tenth of the full capacity, the float makes contact with the relay on the switchboard, so starting the engine at any time of the day or night.

After an interval of time, when the engine has reached full speed, the electric motor driving the pump is automatically put in circuit. The engine continues to work, and the electric motor continues to drive the pump until the supply tank becomes full of water, when the float automatically breaks the circuit and so stops the motor and the engine.

A LISTER-BRUSTON Plant with this attachment will give you a CONTINUOUS SERVICE OF LIGHT and also a CONTINUOUS SERVICE OF WATER without any of the usual bother of constantly watching float gauges or ampere meters as with the ordinary non-automatic plants.

All we ask you to do is to give the engine fuel, oil and water at any convenient time of the day and keep the plant in a reasonably clean condition.
The Heart of a Lighting Plant

WHATEVER type of electric lighting plant you instal, the satisfactory service it will give depends on the ENGINE. No amount of storage battery will make up for a weakness in this essential part. A lighting part is only a machine for converting the mechanical power of the engine into the electrical power that lights your lamps, and if there is not a steady reliable flow of power from the engine the light is uncertain at its very source. The LISTER engine, which is the result of years of experience, coupled with the highest grade of British workmanship and material has made LISTER-BRUSTON plants synonymous with good lighting service and satisfaction.

The operation of this plant is entirely automatic as follows.

1 - 6 K. W. 110 volt type K. S. Lister Bruston Automatic Electric plant.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott.

I beg to give you the following information on the operating of an automatic and a non-automatic electric lighting plant with particular reference to the Kuper Island School. The Lister Bruston is an automatic type of electric lighting plant, and in the case of the Kuper Island School would consist of a 3 K. W. generator, a 6 K. W. generator and an 85 ampere hour storage battery. The operating of this plant is as follows:- Lights can be switched on in any part of the building and the first fifteen lights are supplied from the battery. As soon as more power is required above the fifteen lights the three K. W. generator automatically starts up and generates and supplies current up to its capacity. When more lights are turned on the six K. W. generator automatically starts up and the three K. W. shuts off and power can be used up to the maximum of the six K. W. generator. If more power is required than can be delivered by the six K. W. generator the three K. W. starts up and the entire plant will supply current up to nine K. W. or 9000 watts. In all cases the current above the fifteen lights is being supplied direct from the generators and not from the storage battery. The Lister engine can be operated by either gasoline or petrol.

The non-automatic plant, which uses any type of gasoline engine either directly connected or belt connected to the generator requires a large capacity storage battery of a minimum of 200 ampere hours. In all cases when lights are being used in the building the current is being drawn from the storage battery. The initial cost of the automatic plant is higher than the non-automatic, but the upkeep cost of the automatic is very much lower than the non-automatic, as in the automatic the storage battery costs approximately $500.00 and in the non-automatic $2,000.00. From experience in the past with electric lighting plants in our schools the average life of a storage battery is from three to four years, given good attention. The cost of replacing the storage battery necessitates an expenditure for new batteries every three or four years.
The automatic plant consisting of two generating outfits is also of advantage in isolated locations for if repairs are required to one of the generators current can always be supplied from the other, and the building will not be without lights. Both types of lighting plants of course are guaranteed for a period of years, and there is no difficulty in obtaining good service from the manufacturers of either types or repairing parts.

Specifications of Plants:

One 3 K.W. Plant to standard Lister-Bruston design operating automatically in parallel in the following manner with one 6K.W. Lister-Bruston Plant.

When the Lighting load is first switched on the 3K.W. Plant starts up automatically and carries the load to 90 per cent of its capacity, at which point the 6K.W. Plant starts up automatically and takes over the load and stops the 3K.W. Plant. The 6K.W. Plant carries the load up to its full load rating at which point the 3K.W. Plant is automatically started again and both Plants operate in parallel supplying an output of 9K.W. at 110 Volts.

As the load is decreased the above method of operation is reversed and the 3K.W. Plant is the last one operating, stopping when the load is decreased to the point where it is economical for the battery to carry it.

Further if the 3K.W. Plant fails in operation, the 6K.W. Plant starts up immediately and takes over the load automatically.

Plants equipped with Lister Engines of 5½ H.P. and 12H.P. running at a speed of 550 R.P.M at full load, automatic lubrication, high tension magneto and water cooled.

Dear Sir:

Re-Lighting Plant-Kuper Island School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 28th ultimo authorizing me to accept the tender of Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward for the wiring of the Kuper Island Indian School, at a price of $2,645.00. Your letter of the 28th with further information has also been received.

In reply I beg to say that the tender for the wiring of the School, as specified, the installation of an electric bell and fire gong system, as well as the installation of the lighting fixtures, was awarded to Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward as directed.

You also instructed me to purchase the lighting fixtures, the total cost of which should not exceed $450.00. I would, however, point out that in the original tender of Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward, a price of $706.00 was given for the fixtures and installation of the same. The installation cost, however, is now included in the wiring tender, but just how much this will be I do not know, though it would hardly amount to $250.00. However, you have the sketch of the above fixtures which was attached to Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward original tender on 27th September last and I wish you would send it out to me so that I may know just what to purchase.

With regard to the use of the acetylene gas house for housing the generating plant, some extension will be necessary as the inside dimensions are 11' 10" square, and the Lister-Bruster Company, of Winnipeg, informed me that to conveniently house the plant a building 13' x 18' is necessary. In the centre of the gas house floor there is a circular pit for the gasometer, 5 feet in diameter, which when closed down is 3 inches above the floor level. Therefore this gasometer will have to be removed and the pit filled up with solid concrete if the full space of this building is to be utilized. The removal of the gasometer may be a difficult job. I would suggest, therefore, that an extension of about 13' x 10' be erected, the engines, dynamo and switchboard being installed in the new section with the water-cooling tanks and storage batteries being housed in the old building, a door connecting the two. A raised plank floor could be made to cover the whole of
