Sir:

With further reference to your 15/9422 of the 28th ultimo and to official answering communication, No. 152-0-5 of the 7th instant, I have now to inform you that the Rev. Father Guerts has called at the Department and strongly recommends that a new steam boiler be provided at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. The Provincial Inspector of Boilers writes in part as follows:-

"The boiler is too small for its various purposes, and, as it is a lap seam make, the working pressure will probably be further reduced at next inspection. I advise that, instead of repairing this boiler, a larger one about 48" x 96" with butt strap seam be installed."

Father Guerts explains that steps have not yet been taken to repair the old boiler, and I wish to authorize you now to replace it with a new and larger one. You should make the best possible arrangements and see that there is an early installation.

Rev. Father Guerts is being authorized today to secure what materials are necessary to slightly enlarge the boiler room, as recommended by the firm that installs the boiler. The school management will supply the labour in connection with this small addition.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Re Kuper Island Boiler.

Regarding your conversation with our Mr Brinkman yesterday in connection with additional piping etc required for the above over our contract.

The writer saw Father Gurtz last Sunday in Chemainus and he said that they distinctly understood that the boiler was to be installed complete, and as you know owing to the cramped space inside present boiler house, it was decided to put the new boiler outside and build a new house.

This naturally makes it necessary to have some extra piping and to connect the blow off valve to a point one foot outside new building. Mr Dackett of the Boiler Inspection Dept asked them when they were going to install a new lubricator to the engine, so it was decided we include that.

The 24 extra handhole gaskets we have included at their particular request, also the present trap draining coils in drying room is useless and needs to be replaced.

Therefore our price for the extra steam piping, including one 2" globe valve that is defective, necessary blow off piping to a point one ft outside building, one-1/3 pint Detroit lubricator for engine, 24-4-1/2x2
Handhole Gaskets, and One 1/2" Sarco steam trap for drying room coils is $151.00 (One hundred and fifty one dollars) including sending man to install same, exclusive of Govt Sales Tax.

Mr Gupta told the writer that he considered the Govt should pay for this, but that in the event of their declining to do so, he would pay for same.

We are going ahead and will ship this material with the boiler.

We are pleased to inform you that Mr Peck's Dept in New Westminster approved our design this morning and the boiler is now in hand in the shop.

We are, yours very truly

Victoria Machinery Depot Co Ltd

E.B.A. Wood

Extract from Report of Mr. Indian Agent Graham, for the month of March, 1931, regarding the KUPER ISLAND INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Sanitary conditions, due to toilets being over-crowded and the septic tank system not working, is far from satisfactory.
Water Supply. The water is obtained from springs on the hill behind the school. It is forced by a ram into a tank on a hill near the school. There is also a pump which can be connected either to the tank or to the house direct. Although the quantity may be abundant for domestic purposes, I do not consider that the water in the tank would be of much use in fighting a big fire. As the pressure is only 60 lbs., there would not be the slightest use in trying to get it on to the roof. Should that catch fire, I do not believe that anything could possibly save the school. The above mentioned pump and engine are reported to me by the engineer to be WORN OUT.

Sanitary Conditions. The toilet accommodation is very limited on both sides. There are only 3 toilets for about 50 boys and only 3 toilets for the same number of girls. Moreover, these toilets are so placed that the ventilation is very bad. The boys' toilets are washed out (Floors) twice a day. Still there is quite a smell. I consider that whether or not the school be enlarged, something should be done as soon as possible to enlarge the space available for toilets, and also to arrange for better ventilation. This can be done fairly easily by breaking through the existing outside wall and building a new set of toilets outside the present building. There ought to be at least twice as many toilets on each side.

With the above exception, the whole school is in a splendid state of preservation. It is one of the cleanest schools that I have ever seen. It is hard to believe that it has been occupied since 1925. The diningrooms and kitchens are spotless, as is the rest of the interior.

Domestic Science. This has been touched on under Vocational Training. The girls make all their own dresses and make them very well too. I am told that these children are proud of their ability to make their own clothes. Is not this the spirit we wish to cultivate in the girls? I think that the Sisters have done wonders when they have had such poor sewing machines to work with. There is great need for at least SIX NEW SEWING MACHINES. I wish to recommend that these be sanctioned. The Sister in charge of this work has patched up some old machines but they are wrecks.

Laundry. This is in a very satisfactory condition with the exception of the Steam Coil Drying System. The pipes of this are corroded and need renewal as soon as possible. One section has to be cut out now. Each time that they are mended, they burst again. I should recommend that this work be done during the summer vacation.

Drainage. This is to a septic tank. The overflow pipe from this tank goes to the sea. The logs on the beach have smashed the old pipes. Last year, the school repaired these pipes, but they have been again broken this winter.

I think that there is something wrong with the septic tank. The overflow is not all liquid as it ought to be. I consider that the tank should be opened up and an examination made of the interior. With this tank more or less out of commission and the toilet accommodation so inadequate, there is every chance of serious illness breaking out at this school.

Sir:

Sewage Disposal System,
Kuper Island School.

In compliance with your request, I made an inspection of the sewage disposal works of the above mentioned school on June 2nd. The following is the result of my observations in this connection.

DESCRIPTION

Kuper Island School was built about fifteen years ago, is a brick structure and has a population of about 115. It is situated about fifty feet above sea level and at a distance of approximately 200 feet from the beach.

All drainage water with the exception of that from the roof of the building is intended to pass through a septic tank which has its outlet into the sea.

SEPTIC TANK

I found the septic tank completely filled up with solids, the effluent passing out through an overflow pipe, the outlet pipe solidly obstructed and broken, that portion subject to immersion in sea water, consisting of 4" steel pipe, being irreparably damaged.

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
759 Hastings St. West,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
The septic tank presumably has a capacity of 1,300 gallons daily or about 30% of that necessary for the school population under normal conditions.

There is no ventilating system and the facilities for cleaning are very limited and under present conditions it is impossible for this installation to function as a septic tank.

The conditions at institutions of this type are abnormal, at certain periods, that is, days when the laundry is in operation the drainage flow is very much in excess of the tank capacity and such flow passes directly through the tank without septicising action. Where such conditions prevail separate drainage systems for laundry water and house waste are preferable.

For possibly eight months of the year a septic tank is unnecessary at this institution as the drainage may be conveyed directly to the sea. For a period during midsummer, however, when the children bathe in the vicinity of the wharf it is advisable that sewage pass through the septic tank.

**SUGGESTED IMPROVEMENTS**

The attached plan shows suggestion for overcoming the defects of the present system, the cost of which is estimated at $988.00.

It is proposed that a bypass arrangement be provided to carry the sewage directly to the sea during the period September to May, and on laundry days during the intervening period when the hours of bathing may be restricted, thus obviating
the necessity for a separate outlet for laundry drainage. A new outlet from the septic tank is necessary as the present one is insufficient in size and is beyond repair. In the construction of the outlet it is proposed to bury the pipe in solid rock as the existing pipe line lying on the surface has been frequently damaged by wave action and broken by heavy bodies coming in contact with it.

A satisfactory cleanout arrangement consisting of inspection chamber and outlets from the several tank chambers has been provided. The present facilities are extremely limited and do not encourage the proper clearing of solids as often as is necessary.

Ventilating arrangements which are to be provided are quite essential to ensure proper oxidation of sewage on its passage through the tank and to prevent accumulation of noxious gasses. A vent is also necessary in the main line from the school.

All of the foregoing suggestions have been incorporated in a general scheme for the improvement of the existing system as shown on the accompanying plan and are recommended as best meeting the needs of the school for the disposal of sewage.

The installation of the proposed outlet pipe may be most conveniently undertaken during the latter days of June or the middle of July as tides are lowest then. Otherwise some additional expenditure will be incurred in placing the pipe below water.

Your obedient servant,

W.C. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Cowichan Agency Inspection Report No. 1.

KUPER ISLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Accompanied by Mr. Agent Graham, I visited and inspected this school. I met the Rev. Father Gurtz, the Principal, who seems most efficient, and I found the school well kept, clean, and the children apparently happy and well cared for. I must, however, say that immediately upon my landing, it was forcibly brought to my attention, the unsanitary and unsatisfactory state of the sewerage disposal. This, apparently, is a septic tank and tile drainage system, which has seemingly gone wrong, possibly through clogging of the tile drains, and consequently leaking on the ground. Anyhow, the sewage is pouring out of the ground and running down into the sea. It smells very badly, and I should think is a serious menace to health. Why this particular form of drainage was installed in the first place, instead of running a pipe directly into the sea, no distance at all, I cannot quite understand, as I should have thought it cheaper in the end, and much more reliable. Possibly, there is some regulation against this, though the Island is some miles from the mainland, and I don't see why. I should therefore recommend that this matter receive immediate attention, and if feasible, the main drainage be piped directly into the sea.

There were 95 children in residence at the time of my visit. There are only three toilets for the use of the boys, with very poor ventilation. I should suggest, in agreement with the Principal, that toilets for the boys be erected in the form of a lean-to addition to the building, and that where the toilets are now, three showers be installed. The pressure tank cannot be used as the pump is out of order, and is apparently worn out. There is supposed to be 60 pounds pressure for fire fighting purposes, but with this machinery out of order, there is, of course, no use for the hydrants and hose. Everything else in the building seemed in good order. The kitchen, though small was clean. Good work is being done in the Manual training class, though this building is small, having only room for six benches. This school, too could do with a second hand marine engine and quarters for it for instructional purposes. At the time of my visit the children were having fish, potatoes, bread etc., for their midday meal. Cultivation was good and the children getting instruction in farm work and vegetable growing. The local doctor was paying a visit to the school when I was there.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

In reply I have to say, with regard to the sewage disposal and other sanitary matters, that the Dominion Water Power Branch was requested to undertake the work required in carrying out the necessary repairs to the septic tank, and a cheque to the amount of $1,000 has been forwarded to their District Chief Engineer towards the cost. In the report received from the Engineer he estimated the cost of the repairs at $985 and stated that from the end of June to the middle of July would be the most convenient time to do this work, as the tides are then at their lowest.

Regarding the Inspector's report that a marine gas engine is required for the instruction of the pupils, I have to say that we have no funds to provide the cost of supplying this equipment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

W. E. Ditchburn, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Box 666, Victoria, B.C.
Duncan, B. C.

September 24th, 1931.

Sir:

On visiting Kuper Island Residential School this week with Mr. School Inspector Barry, the Reverend Principal pointed out to me the state of the engine and pump for water purposes in the School. These have got into such a bad state that it is quite impossible to get any pressure at all, and in case of fire, there is no protection at all; and the only water that would be available would be from the gravity tank that is filled by the rain, and this supply is so limited that it would give little or no protection.

The R. A. Lister Co., have looked into this and stated that they could install a first class automatic system for about $300.

I would certainly like to recommend that something be done in order to give some fire protection for the School.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

There is, at present, accommodation for about 100 pupils and a staff of seven. The authorization for an increase of five pupils, from 95 to 100, from October 1st, was given by the Department some short time ago. I am very anxious that this school should be enlarged. It would not be difficult to enlarge each wing of the building. I am also informed by Mr. Indian Agent Graham that there would be little difficulty in finding another 60 children in his Agency. I should like to see accommodation provided for 30 boys and 30 girls in addition to the present 100 authorized.

This school is a very well administered institution. The building is in excellent condition, and the suggested extension of each wing would make it possible to arrange for proper toilets on the ground level, an increase to the rather small kitchen space, besides providing excellent educational advantages for the children in the Agency who at present are not going to school.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Your beautiful picture of the Annunciation has arrived in perfect condition. It is in its place in the chapel now. Everybody admires it very much. Its colouring harmonises very well with our chapel, and it is very devotional. The frame you put it in is very rich, and quite in keeping with the picture. Among the many favors shown us during your visit here, there is none I appreciate more than the donation of this artistic picture. I cannot find words to adequately express my gratitude for all you have done for our school. Many are the visitors who have come to our school during the summer months. Dear Doctor:

I forwarded to you on Monday the tender of Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward, for the wiring and lighting plant for the Kuper Island Indian School. When you wrote to me on this subject the Conservatives held the rein of power, and as Mr. Hayward, of the above mentioned firm is a brother of one of the representatives for Victoria in the local house and a Conservative, I did not think I could go far wrong in asking this firm to tender. On the other hand, Mr. Hawkins has, I believe, identified himself with the Liberals here and so I do not think there will be any objections raised by the politicians to this firm obtaining the work providing you consider the prices right. As stated in my official letter, however, this firm is the biggest electrical one in Victoria and would, I consider, be best qualified to handle a contract such as that under consideration.

I missed your signature on correspondence coming from your office for some time and naturally concluded you were on vacation, which I trust you thoroughly enjoyed and feel improved in health for your rest.

There has been quite a tangle at Ottawa for some time which undoubtedly tied up departmental business, but now that we shall have a stable government, matters will, no doubt, be carried on in a much more satisfactory manner.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to the matter of obtaining tenders for the lighting plant at the Kuper Island Indian School, I beg to say there seems to be a feeling among the firms who have been asked to quote that Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward have an unfair advantage over them by reason of the fact that as they have been lately appointed the B. C. Agents for the sale of the Lister-Bruston Generating Plants, they have quoted a price and terms on the same to the other tenderers by which the plant will cost them considerably more than Hawkins & Hayward could obtain it for themselves. The price of the plant is $5,375.00, f.o.b. Winnipeg and allowing a discount of only 5%. Mr. Grant, of the Grant Electric Company, one of the proposed tenderers, informed me the other day that he got a figure from the Winnipeg house (at that time there being a B. C. Agent) at the same price, ($5,375.00) less 10% and 5% which would allow of a discount of $776.00 as against $268.75.

Just when Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward were appointed Agents for B. C. I am not certain, but I am very much inclined to the opinion it was after they had put in their first bid. Mr. A.E. Wilson, of 367-19th Avenue West, Vancouver, who is a representative of the R.A. Lister Company of Winnipeg, came to see me last week about the plant and I informed him that I did not like the idea of his appointing as Agent a firm which was in competition with other tenderers, but he stated that any firm could purchase the generating plant from Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward at the same price as Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward, could themselves, and they should have no unfair advantage of the others. Mr. Grant's latter statement, however, would not appear to bear this out. I understood from Mr. Wilson that our Department could purchase the generating plant specified at a much lower price than it could be by any private individual or electrical dealer.

I would therefore suggest, in order that this proposed contract be removed from the realm of complaint, that the Department purchase the generating plant from the Winnipeg house direct, and have it installed by the company's man, the cost of which, I understand, is $2,255.00 and expenses. The specifications covering the same will be added and the local firms asked to tender on the wiring and electric bell system only, the successful one being given the contract for the fixtures and installation of the same.

I am attaching hereto a copy of the letter written by Messrs. Hawkins & Hayward to the Grant Electric Company setting forth the price and terms of payment on the Lister-Bruston Generating Plant which is specified for.

I expect to have all the tenders in the office by Monday, the 15th instant.

Yours sincerely,

Indian Commissioner
for B. C.

It is considered that, if the batteries were not overloaded and if they were used for no other purpose than for lighting, they should have lasted longer than three years. Dear Sir:

In answer to letter of Department No152-0-5 re new batteries would say that I have a mechanic in charge who previously had experience with electrical sets on boats, and is now making a special study of electricity. 2o- There is no electrical attachments for washing machines. 3o- re pumping water: as we have a ram the electrical pump is very seldom used; and when used, always at such times when there are hardly any lights on and the small engine alone is able to carry the load. As to the pumping for laundry purposes, once every two weeks, most of it is done between 8 and 12 o'clock when practically no lights are used.

Finally I would say that although 2 engines have been installed for the lighting system it almost never occurs that the two are in operation at the same time.

Now as to say that it is absolutely urgent to replace the old set at once this is hard to say. But the fact is that two cells have already been discarded; that a third one, now frequently tested may have to go any time; and how long will the others hold out even an electrician could not give an exact date. But in my humble opinion I think it would be a wise thing to have a new set ready so that in case the old one gives out, we are not left without lights until the new ones arrive.

Yours obediently

[Signature]
Principal.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, regarding the supplying of new batteries for the lighting plant at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School and enclosing copy of communication which you received from the Reverend Principal, concerning the replacing of the batteries now in use.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will provide the funds required to supply this new equipment. It is considered that the offer made by the Globelite Batteries, Limited, Winnipeg, to supply a battery of 160 ampere hour capacity, corresponding with their type 56 cell G. D. 13 battery, would be satisfactory. It is noted that, in their communication to the Rev. Principal, dated November 16th, last, which was forwarded under cover of your letter of the 25th of the same month, they quote a net price, less discounts, of $373.80, f. o. b. Winnipeg. Sales Tax of 6% extra, for supplying this battery. You or the Rev. Principal may place an order with the above firm to supply the battery of the type mentioned and at the price quoted by them. This would make the price of the above equipment $373.80 net, plus $22.43 sales tax - a total of $396.23, f. o. b. Winnipeg. The Company should prepay the freight charges from Winnipeg to the School and obtain a receipt for the amount paid. They should be furnished with the necessary shipping directions. Their account, in triplicate, should be forwarded to you, with the receipt for freight charges attached. You will then attach the account to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

For your information, I am returning herewith the communication which the Principal received from the Globelite Batteries, Limited, Winnipeg. When forwarding the account in payment for the new batteries, please attach the letter to it.

It would appear that the offer made by the above firm would be the best solution in having new batteries supplied. It is presumed the school authorities will be able to install the batteries when they arrive. The purchase and delivery of this equipment should receive early attention, in order that the account can be received in time to be paid before the end of the present fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

One Horizontal return tubular Boiler, 66" in diameter and 12' long, containing fifty 4" x 12' tubes, No. 22020 B.C., Longitudinal joint treble rivetted lap, rated at 84 H.P., built in 1915 making it now 18 years old.

One Vertical tubular boiler, 48" in diameter and 96" high, containing 127 - 2" x 72" tubes, No. 22563 B.C., Longitudinal joint double rivetted butt, rated at 26 H.P., built in 1927, making it now 6 years old.

One vertical steam engine, 7" diameter by 8" stroke, used to operate the Laundry Machinery.

One double set of Lister Gasoline Engines D.C. to Generators. Engines are of 3 and 6 H.P., Generators are 6 and 12 K.W.

Fresh water is supplied to the school from a natural rock spring pumped to a high distributing tank by a Hydraulic Ram. Also there is an auxiliary electric pumping unit to be used in case the ram fails, which I was informed has not yet occurred.

Boiler No. 22563 B.C.

This is a vertical tubular boiler used for the laundry engine and machines.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found that all the stays, rivets, and plates were in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 240 lbs. per square inch and found all seams quite tight. Several tubes were leaking on the top plate. These will need re-expanding, which can be done by the staff.

I then checked the safety valve which works freely and blows off at 125 lbs.

Internally this boiler is not in the best of condition owing to the hardness of the feed water. The tubes are very badly scaled and there is quite a lot of loose scale on the top of the lower tube sheet and wet-lags. This must all be removed. Apparently most of this scale came from the tubes around the water line and in the near future many of these tubes will commence to leak as they will be eaten through.

I would recommend that when this boiler is not in operation it be kept empty and when refilled that a strong solution of Sal. Soda be added to the feed water in the proportion of 1/2 lb. Sal. Soda to 1 gallon of clear lime water, each time it is operated. If this should cause a slight foaming of the boiler decrease the amount of soda 25%.

The fusible plug must be renewed. The test gauges and water glass are in good condition as well as the main stop valves and blowdown cock and pipes.

The Steam Gauge is 3 lb. light.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 125 lbs but on account of the tubes, the condition fair.

Boiler No. 22020 B.C.

This is a horizontal return tubular boiler and is used for heating the School.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found all the rivets and plates in good condition. One of the through stays sounded a little slack and I tightened it. They are all now in good condition.

I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test. Upon reaching 10 lb. the joint between the main stop valve and the boiler blew out. Apparently this has been giving trouble as from appearances the nuts have been tightened before. This will need a new gasket which can be installed by the staff.

The internal condition of this boiler is very fair. Many of the tubes have scale blisters, but upon removing them there were not any pits showing. From present appearances I do not think that there will be any tube trouble for some time, but on account of the isolated position of this School I would recommend that three bolt tube-stoppers be procured so that if a tube leaks it can be stopped in a few minutes and permanent repairs made during the off season. I would also recommend that a solution of Sal Soda and lime water be added to the feed water in the proportion of 1 lb. sal soda to 5 gallons clear lime water at least twice each firing season.

The blowdown pipe is getting quite thin and must be renewed next summer.

The fusible plug must be renewed.

The safety valves work freely and blow off at 5 lb. pressure. The discharge of these valves is connected to the smoke uptake. This is not a good practice as it corrodes the uptake and also makes it very awkward for the attendant to know when they are blowing off or leaking.

The test gauge, water gauge, blowdown cock and steam gauge are in good condition.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 5 lbs and condition good. No repairs required to the brickwork or firebars.
Laundry.

The steam engine is kept in very good condition. All the bearings are quite tight and in good condition.

The laundry has two washing machines, one 28" Hydro extractor, one open-slat wringer. All the machines appear well kept but there should be a pipe guard placed around the belt pulleys and gear of both washing machines and the slat wringer. I pointed this out to the attendant. EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR BARRY ON HIS VISIT TO THE KUPER ISLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - FEBRUARY 6 and 7, 1934.

SANITARY CONDITION:
The toilet accommodation is very limited. On the ground floor there are only 3 toilets for about 50 boys, and the same number for the 50 girls. As previously recommended the provision of increased toilet accommodation is to be desired; but I do not believe that any temporary building should be undertaken with a view to the provision of more accommodation. The matter is linked up with the building of additions to each wing of the present school. It is however necessary that the very limited number of toilets now provided are in working order. I am sorry to state that the toilets throughout the building are nearly worn out. Those on the ground floor require renewal AT ONCE. I have to most strongly recommend the provision of SIX NEW TOILET BOWLS, SEATS AND SMALL TANKS - three to be placed on the boys' side and three on the girls' side to take the place of toilet fixtures quite worn out. This is a very urgent matter, and the Indian Agent may have reported on it as he and the Principal were with me when we inspected the present toilet accommodation.

DRAINAGE:
The work done in 1931 with respect to the pipe to the sea is giving good service. The drainage, I am informed, is being run directly into the sea below low water mark. It is not being run through the septic tank. If the septic tank is to be used in future it will require to be cleaned out by other than the boys at the school; but I do not believe that the tank need be used as long as the pipe to the sea remains unbroken. The Principal spoke of filling in the present septic tank. This would be a very foolish thing to do, as it may be required in the future. I recommend that this point be taken up in writing to the Principal.

PAINTING:
The woodwork of the outside of the school requires to be repainted. This has not been done for 17 or 18 years. The gutters around the roof, particularly in the front of the school require renewal. The present shingles have been on the roof for 18 years. The roof needs to be reshingled at an early date. I would recommend that this work of painting, reshingling the roof, and supplying new gutters be allowed for in the estimates for the year 1935-36.
Ottawa, March 7th, 1934.

Sir:

February 11th, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to report that I paid my monthly visit to Kuper Island Indian Residential School on January 29th, last, in company with Mr. School Inspector Barry.

The Reverend Principal took us around on a tour of inspection, and pointed out four things that required attention:

1. The floors of the boys and girls play rooms is completely gone. These floors have apparently been built so close to the ground that there was no ventilation with the result that the sills have all rotted away, and both floors will have to come up and be completely renewed.

2. The Sister in charge of the kitchen complained that the range was far too small, it being only a two oven, and that one oven was almost gone. On examining the same I found that it was so badly bulged that it will not last very much longer, which means that the stove would have to be replaced, and I would like to recommend that a new one be installed, the same to cost about $300.00.

3. On the whole of the second floor, the walls require refacing with kalsomine and the wood-work painted; this work could be done by the school staff, and the material for the same would cost about $100.00.

4. They are very badly off for a large sewing machine. The only one that they have at present, that is of any real value, is a single taylor machine, which is two years old, and then three ordinary machines. As the majority of the work to be done, is all more or less heavy material for boy's overalls, etc., it is too much for the ordinary machines, and the one tayloring machine has to do it all.

I would like to recommend the above improvements be carried out at this school, as they are badly needed.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent,

Painting:

The woodwork of the outside of the school requires to be repainted. This has not been done for 16 or 19 years. The gutters around the roof require renewal. These should be renewed at the same time that the roof is reshingled. Last year I recommended that the funds necessary for reshingling the roof of the main school be asked for in the 1935-36 estimates. I certainly hope that this has been done, as the matter of reshingling has now become urgent. I would recommend that this very necessary work be done during the summer of 1935, this year. It will be understood that the roof here by the sea has been doing duty for twenty-one years. There is moss on it in a number of places now. I am anxious that damage to the interior of the school be avoided and I am thus recommending this work. The Indian Agent, Mr. Graham, agrees with me I know in this, and I understand he will also report with regard to this matter.

A certain amount of interior painting has been done since my last inspection. Some of the smaller rooms and some of the passage ways have been painted, after the cracks in plaster work have been filled. The work done is excellent. The Principal asks for $100.00 to buy paint so that he can have the remaining passage ways and several of the rooms painted. This does not refer to the dormitories, which should not be so painted. It is necessary to keep the school in good repair and if we can have the cracks in the plaster and a few small holes repaired and the painting of the remainder of the passages and small rooms done at the school at only the cost of the material, I think it would be justifiable to supply the necessary paint on the understanding that the sum of $100.00 was not exceeded.

Sir:

In further reference to Departmental letter dated February 19th, in connection with my letter asking for certain improvements for the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, acting on your instructions in connection with renewing of the floors in the boys and girls play rooms, I beg to report that I have had a contractor go into this thoroughly.

Reverend Father Geurts, was most anxious that a terraza floor be laid, but this would cost $2327.00; a cement floor with Red Hardiner would cost $750.00, and the same work in wood, which would require new joint, No.1, K.D.E.G. flooring, layed, stained and varnished - $425.00. Sir,

In company with Mr. Agent Graham I inspected the Kuper Island Res. School today.

Mr. Graham wrote you on the 10th instant with regard to certain improvements required at this school but the total amount mentioned by him was considerably in excess of the amount provided in this year's appropriation.

I would recommend that Agent Graham be authorized to purchase the new kitchen stove mentioned in his letter, also to authorize him to purchase the material required for the addition to the kitchen. The cost of both these improvements would be less than $400.00. Tell Mr. Graham that Department expects school management to supply the work, which I know they are prepared to do.

In addition to the above, the floor in the boys' playroom will have to be renewed. If the Department would supply lumber etc. to the value of $286.00, I feel certain that the school staff would do the work. This means a larger expenditure than included in estimates but these improvements are absolutely necessary this year and the above suggestions are the cheapest way to have them done, and if at all possible I would recommend immediate instructions being given Mr. Graham, in order that the school staff can go ahead as soon as the children leave for holidays at the end of this month.

This school is in good condition. It was erected in 1915 and is in good condition, although the roof will have to be reshingled next year. The interior of the building is also in good shape, the principal having supplied from school funds linoleum for all the halls and rooms. I enclose pictures showing the garden in front of the school towards the ocean. All the flowers are in bloom now and it is a very pleasing sight.

Sir:

On my last monthly visit to Kuper Island Residential School, my attention was drawn by the Reverend Principal, to the state of the shingles on the main building. These are beginning to go very fast; one can see daylight through in many places. On the north side they have become so moss grown that they will be a menace from fire during the dry weather. The gutters around the edge have completely gone, which allows all the water to come down the sides of the building and is beginning to have an effect on the bricks and the cement foundation.

I made provision for these and other improvements in my yearly estimates, and I sincerely trust that the Department is giving this very favourable consideration, for if not eventually the cost will be much greater for repairs, for it will not be long before the roof is leaking so badly it will affect the plaster inside the building.

I might say I visited the school with Mr. School inspector Barry this week and I went into this question very fully with the Principal, and in order to do this work economically it must all be done at one time, as scaffolding for a high building like this must be erected in order to do the work, as it is too high to use ladders and the gutter all around the building must be repaired, as metal gutters were put in originally, and that is rusted through and is leaking very badly all around the building, which is having the effect of cracking the concrete and bricks where it is constantly running down the walls, and if this is not done immediately it will cause a great deal of expense later on, so whatever work is done this Summer, this is most essential. The scaffolding would have to be erected all around the building in order to put in the new gutters and also to do the painting.

On the west side of the building the shingles are not quite so bad, as on the east side which is very moss grown and is beginning the rot the sheeting to which the shingles are attached, and if this side is not done very soon, it will mean replacing the sheeting, which will add to the cost.

If it is impossible to provide the full amount applied for to have this work done, I would suggest that the Department give us all that is possible, and we will have the gutter, painting and as much shingling done as possible, the balance then will have to be left until next year, which will mean the heavy extra expense of erecting the scaffolding again to complete the shingling.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Having further reference to mine of the 20th, of March and your reply of the 27th, re. repairs needed to the roof of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, and in which you advise me that there is $2,500.00 available for repairs to this roof.

I took the matter up with a contractor, but could get nothing definite from him, so went to the school and went into the matter very carefully with the Reverend Principal. He suggested that the Church Authorities had carpenters available that by boarding at the school, we could get the work done very much cheaper, and in this way a lot of the simpler work could be done by the school staff, and in that way save money.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Funds, to the amount of $2,500.00, have been provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year to repair the roof of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, Chemainus, Federal Electoral District of Nanaimo, B.C. This school is a government-owned institution and was erected in the year 1916. The roof is badly in need of re-shingling and the gutters require renewal. It has now become urgent that the work be carried out, in order to prevent damage through further leakage.

The local Indian Agent, Mr. H. Graham, Duncan, B.C., reported that he interviewed the Principal regarding the work required. The Principal suggested to the Agent that the church authorities have carpenters available and that, by boarding them at the school while they are doing the work, it could be carried out very much cheaper, and, in this way, the school staff could assist and perform considerable of the work. The Agent recommends that No. 1 cedar shingles be used. He requests that he be given permission to purchase the shingles and other materials required and arrange with the church authorities for the labour, utilizing the services of their carpenters.

I should be pleased to have your authority to incur an expenditure to the amount of $2,500 for material and labour in repairing the roof and to be advised if it will be satisfactory to utilize the services of the carpenters which the church authorities have available in carrying out the labour. I should also be pleased to be informed of the name of the firm from whom the shingles should be obtained. The Agent states that he would supervise the work and see that a satisfactory job is done for the money available.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

With further reference to your letter of May 8th, in connection with repairs to the Kuper Island Indian Residential School and notifying me that $2500.00 was available for this work, I have had several consultations with the Reverend Principal of the school and staff in regard to getting this work done, and after going into it very closely, they decided that owing to the fact that it is such a high building and the staging had to be built up all the way around, they were afraid that it was really more than they could tackle, as the risk was too great. We then decided to call in Messrs Inkster & Thompson, who are on the approved list, and who are cheaper than the other firm whose name was given me by you, so we have decided to go ahead with the work under Messrs Inkster & Thompson's supervision, that is the most dangerous, and the school representatives will do the remainder.

As Messrs Inkster & Thompson are doing the most dangerous work on the 5% supervision basis, we figured that this would be cheaper than we could do it ourselves, but the remainder will be carried out under the Reverend Principal's and my own supervision, and I think I can say that we will guarantee to get good value for the money expended, and I hope put the school in very good shape for some years to come.

We have ordered our material as we are anxious to get it hauled before the school children go home for their vacation on the 26th of June.

Trusting that the Department approve of our action in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Having further reference to authority given me in Departmental letter dated May 8th, last to make certain repairs to Kuper Island Indian Residential School, I have already sent forward one lot of vouchers in connection with this work, and I am now enclosing Voucher No.500, for $670.73- in favor of Reverend J. Geurts, covering money he has paid out, as per the receipted accounts attached to the voucher, and I am also enclosing copy of letter from Rev. Geurts.

I may say that when the Auditor was at the school the work was proceeding, and we had no means of paying this except by vouchers to the Department, and Mr. Holmes suggested that Reverend Father Geurts pay them, and take regular receipts, and send them in as I am now doing.

You will notice that there is a balance according to my figures of $83.59 which I intend to spend on repairs to Fire escapes, also for new screens for the windows around the base of the building, as the windows are for ever getting broken by small stones flying against them.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
